When analyzing the cases in which one of the models, rather than both, produced inaccurate track forecasts, it was found that a considerably large number of poor forecasts were made in the area between 20°N and 24.9°N, 65°W and 69.9°W by either one of the models, a region of the Atlantic basin in which many TCs recurve as the mean flow changes and vertical shear increases. Finally, the synoptic environments in which these poor forecasts occurred were evaluated. Patterns in the orientations of the forecast and observed tracks in the 90th percentile of track error were analyzed and grouped into four categories: vertical ladder, horizontal ladder, funnel, and timing error. In addition, synoptic-scale features potentially related to these large error patterns, such as the subtropical high and the presence of other TCs, were analyzed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Editions for classical guitar: a philologically based method

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Classical Guitar, Critical Edition, Music Editing, Music Philology

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The written record of music (the score) has an extremely important role in the development of music in its various forms of action in society, with the editor being the professional responsible for preparing the musical text to be published, to be made available to society, they are the bridge between the composer and the reader.This treatise aims the development of a guide to the guitarist editor based on the practices and standards of the philology area. Philology is the area of science that deals with the study of text, from its origin to its impact on society, the preparation of texts is one of the branches of philology, our objective is to adapt philological editing methods to the music area, comparing and taking advantage of the methods already used by music editors.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Best and Brightest: An Investigation into Florida's Teacher Scholarship and Teacher Retention

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Best and Brightest, Florida, Logistic Regression, Recruitment, Retention, Teacher Scholarship

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effects of Florida’s Best and Brightest Teacher Scholarship on the retention rates of “High-Quality” Teachers. In 2015, the state provided $44 million for recruitment and retention bonuses of $10,000. In subsequent years, the program was reduced in size of award until ultimately canceled in 2020. The program used teachers’ SAT or ACT scores (specifically if their score was above the 80th percentile) to determine if a teacher would qualify for the award. If they were not a new teacher, they would submit a combination of SAT/ACT scores and their principal’s evaluation. I use logistic regression to estimate the influence the policy had on the rates of retention. I do not address the effects on recruitment due to sample size limitations. Further, I estimate if the program was more influential based on the subjects that teachers were certified to teach and defined by Florida as critical shortage areas subjects. Finally, I report on the differential rates of retention as the size of the award varied after the decrease in award amount. The findings are that the teacher scholarship was related to an increase in retention for critical shortage area subject teachers who received the award, as well as the entire sample of educators who received the award. No effects were found for early career teachers. The policy implications are addressed, and future research avenues are discussed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Language Mindsets as Sources of Emotions: An Experimental Study of International Graduate Students in the U.S.

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: International graduate students, L2 enjoyment, L2 motivation, L2 speaking anxiety, Language mindsets

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Mindsets have been gaining popularity recently in the field of second language acquisition (SLA). There have been studies exploring language mindsets in relation to emotions such as anxiety and fear of failure (e.g., Lou & Noels, 2017), anxiety, rejection sensitivity, contact avoidance, and willingness to interact (e.g., Lou & Noels, 2020a), language anxiety, use of language, and reported language proficiency (e.g., Lou & Noels, 2020b), anxiety and confidence (e.g., Ozdemir & Papi, 2021), and L2 grit (e.g., Khajavy, et al., 2020; Teimouri, et al., 2022). Although these studies help scholars to understand the relationship between mindsets and emotions, there is a gap in the literature of SLA in terms of language mindsets intervention. There are only a few studies implementing an intervention to change students’ language mindsets in the field of psychology (e.g., Lou & Noels, 2016, 2020a). In order to fill in the gap of the lack of intervention studies in the field of SLA, the current study implemented a language mindset intervention with international graduate students to change their fixed language mindsets to growth language mindsets. For this purpose, 108 participants were recruited for Phase 1 of the study. Out of 108 participants, 61 of them were eligible to take part in Phase 2. However, 60 participants’ data were analyzed because 1 participant wanted to skip the writing part, which was part of the intervention and the manipulation check. Out of 60 participants, 57 of them were willing to participate in Phase 3. The results revealed that fixed language mindset predicted L2 speaking anxiety, whereas growth language mindset was a predictor of L2 enjoyment. There was a significant change in language speaking performance for the growth language mindset condition in terms of lexical and syntactic errors and fillers. The use of errors and fillers decreased in the growth language mindset condition. On the other hand, there was an increase in lexical diversity in the fixed language mindset condition. Theoretical and educational implications will be discussed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Love of My Life

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: adultery, bildugsroman, creative nonfiction, memoir, military, oregon

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: A memoir excerpt about growing up in a home with an abusive mother, marrying a controlling Army infantryman, and falling in love with an emotionally distant Marine.

DISS_description.DISS_title: AN EXPLORATION OF SCIENCE IDENTITY DEVELOPMENT SUPPORTED BY JUSTICE-ORIENTED SCIENCE PEDAGOGY WITHIN A COUNTERSPACE

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Counterspace, Justice-oriented science pedagogy, Science identity

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This qualitative study explores a pedagogical approach that centered participants' epistemic authority to select the ways of knowing and focus for their practices of science. Guided by Black feminist theory, the program facilitators and participants engaged multiple cultural practices to (re)define science practices and (re)center participants’ intersectional identities within the praxis of a liberatory and loving pedagogy. Participants explored and challenged their initial ideas of science as the group collectively considered diverse ways of knowing and spent time in reflection around practices of inquiry that are not typically recognized as science. Then, to support the science identity development of participants, facilitators engaged participants in designing and enacting science inquiries to provide opportunities for science performance, recognition, and competence. Participants concluded the program with reflections on the experience and the tools they gained, including their perspectives on themselves as science people. Through the methodology of portraiture, participants and researcher together explored and organized three stories that attend to details within lived experiences, including actions, emotions, and thoughts. The portraits are organized around the themes of science identity, race, and gender and attend to the relational elements that position participants as knowledge holders and science people. This critical study may benefit others by showing how epistemic injustice in science education can be healed within learning contexts that attend to power and justice.

DISS_description.DISS_title: POST AUDIT OF A SUBREGIONAL GROUNDWATER FLOW MODEL: SIMULATED VS. MEASURED DISCHARGE AT WAKULLA SPRING AND IMPLICATIONS FOR FUTURE MODELING

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: In groundwater modeling, the term “post audit” refers to a method of verifying simulated (predicted) data produced by a groundwater model against analogous measured data. According to Anderson et. al., (2015), evaluation of model performance includes two components: a “hard knowledge” evaluation which compares direct field measurements with simulated values; and a “soft knowledge” evaluation of the conceptual flow model. This two-pronged approach applies relevant concepts from the literature, site conditions, hydrogeological principles, and professional experience to comprehensively evaluate the suitability of model assumptions, parameters, and performance with respect to the hydrogeologic system, purpose of investigation, and available resources. If a model fails to achieve an acceptable history-match with measured data or applies unreasonable calibration parameters, the model must be modified or discarded (Anderson et. al., 2015). Of course, a universal standard of what may be considered “suitable” or “reasonable” in groundwater modeling is not possible, as any interpretations made to this effect inherently depend upon the hydrogeologist’s experience with the problem at hand. Therefore, any such interpretations must be substantiated by quality data, and include the caveat that human error may give rise to inherent or random bias in these interpretations. In the interest of supporting environmental management efforts, the subject thesis investigation is a post audit of the Davis subregional groundwater flow model, which evaluates the accuracy of model-predicted discharge at Wakulla Spring from 2010 through 2018. This investigation is structured with the intent to resolve causal mechanisms of anomalous discharge trends at Wakulla Springs over time. Parameters compared for this evaluation were selected based on the model purpose and model calibration approach. These parameters include simulated and measured spring discharge at Wakulla Spring’s main vent, plus simulated and measured hydraulic heads from 4 wells close to Wakulla Springs from 2010 through 2018. The quantitative accuracy of model-predicted discharge and hydraulic head is evaluated by applying standard statistical methods in groundwater modeling. The Nash-Sutcliffe coefficient and the Root Mean Square Error for model “residuals” (measured values minus simulated values) describe error associated with model-predicted spring discharge and hydraulic head values, respectively. Model error statistics are considered with respect to the model purpose, design, and observed system behavior. Results of the post audit evaluation culminate in two main conclusions which support model updates to optimize utility and overall accuracy of the subregional model, rendering a robust tool in support of conservation and water resource planning near Wakulla Springs. Based on evaluation of post audit results and hydrologic data, it is proposed that recharge rate simulated simulated during stress periods 50 and 54 (corresponding to years 2010 and 2014) in the numerical model should be updated to reflect all sources of recharge in the groundwater contribution area. This update is suggested in accordance with observed changes in permitted wastewater discharges in the immediate recharge area for Wakulla Springs between 2010 and 2014. Additionally, the conceptual model of groundwater flow may benefit from an update that accounts for two mechanisms that are unique to hydrologic conditions of the study area. These mechanisms include anthropogenic drivers of system recharge, and conduit flows associated with karst lake dry down events during times of seasonal drought. These conclusions are significant because they optimize the potential for future application of this model to relevant management issues; offer a mechanistic understanding of anomalous flow trends observed in recent years at Wakulla Springs; and demonstrate the sensitivity of first magnitude karst springs to anthropogenic inputs.

DISS_description.DISS_title: UNDERSTANDING THE INITIAL UTILIZATION AND IMPACT OF PROGRAMMATIC GRANT FUNDING AT FLORIDA COLLEGE SYSTEM INSTITUTIONS DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC: INSIGHTS FROM THE FIELD

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Florida, funding, grants, pandemic, resource development

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The COVID-19 pandemic was a unique phenomenon that significantly impacted higher education. Programmatic grants were an important source of funding at community colleges during this unusual time, helping to provide vital resources and support services to institutions and their students. This study is one of the first of its kind to explore the utilization and impact of programmatic grants at Florida College System institutions during the initial phases of the COVID-19 pandemic between March 2020-August 2021. The data sources for this study are the directors of the grants offices of the colleges that make up the Florida College System. Using a survey method design, I investigated how Florida College System institutions utilized programmatic grant funding during the pandemic, the impact of this grant funding, and the potential sustainability of these grant programs. I found that Florida College System institutions are most likely to have used grant funds during the pandemic on Scholarships and Technology/Distance Learning Support. Most Florida College System institutions indicated they received a larger amount of programmatic grant funding during the COVID-19 pandemic as compared to before the pandemic. I also found that the most common impact of programmatic grants during the pandemic was the expansion of student support services. Federal and state governments were the most common sources of programmatic grant funding at Florida College System institutions during the 2020-2021 pandemic.

DISS_description.DISS_title: CONTENDING WITH LANGUAGE DIFFERENCE IN THE WRITING CENTER: AN INVESTIGATION OF ATTITUDES AND EXPECTATIONS TOWARD SECOND LANGUAGE WRITERS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Second Language Writing, Writing Center, Writing Studies

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Laura Greenfield and Karen Rowen argue that in order to realize the change potential within tutor education, writing center directors must look critically at how we have been designing and executing our tutor education courses. This dissertation addresses the call to examine the additional factors on which tutor education can be structured or restructured and what ideologies about language, and specifically second-language use, inhibit writing center administrators ability to decouple tutor-training from the unidirectional monolinguistic ideals that have historically been at the center of writing instruction. As one site of both language instruction and writing support, writing centers are an optimal space to analyze the assumptions that administrators and tutors bring to working with multilingual students. The writing center tutor education course is often where tutors learn the tacit theories that tell them what is “right” or “normal” in the writing center.

I followed Johanek’s (2000) lead in adopting an epistemologically mixed approach to this study. By “epistemologically mixed,” I mean it accounts for multiple ways of knowing. This study uses CDA as its methodological grounding because it takes into account the social act of knowing and enables a researcher to analyze linguistic and semiotic details in light of larger social and political or, in the case of my study, institutional contexts. Huckin et al. (2012) describes critical discourse analysis “as an interdisciplinary approach to textual study that aims to explicate abuses of power promoted by those texts, by analyzing linguistic/semiotic details in light of the larger social and political contexts in which those texts circulate” (p. 107). Because I examined the attitudes and expectations about second language writing through the use of interviews, it was essential that this research was grounded in a methodology that accounts for both the context and theory.

This study has three key findings: (a) writing Center Administrators who had experience in either linguistics or TESOL took a more second language studies approach while those that had little or no formal preparation in TESOL or linguistics took a more translingual approach to working on language diversity; (b) when writing center administrators lacked expertise in expertise in the very areas that their L2/ESL/residential multilingual students need they have a tendency to hook onto the agendas that they can understand; and (c) one of the central reasons that writing center administrators are hesitant to train tutors to offer linguistic feedback is because they are afraid of being labeled as racist, or not anti-racist enough.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Ramos Mariachi Violin Method

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Mariachi, Pedagogy, Violin

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The Ramos Mariachi Violin Method treatise is an overview of Books 1 and 2 of an original violin teaching method. These method books teach violin and Spanish language vocal technique through carefully paced mariachi and Spanish language children’s songs. Each song serves a pedagogical function and teaches incrementally paced violin skills such as bow strokes, left hand finger dexterity, sound quality, bow articulation, rhythm, and intonation. In addition to teaching violin pedagogy, the Ramos Mariachi Violin Method prepares the student to sing and perform violin on each song. Upon completing this method’s series of books, the violin student will have developed a solid foundation of violin skills that fosters the musicianship and technical proficiency that is essential to violin playing. In addition, these same students will learn to sing Spanish language mariachi songs, preparing them with the ensemble and vocal skills necessary to sing and play mariachi music with a full band. In this way, students can learn to play the violin, while simultaneously celebrating mariachi music and Mexican culture.

DISS_description.DISS_title: AFRICAN AMERICAN MUSIC THERAPISTS TREATING AFRICAN AMERICAN CLIENTS: A CONTENT ANALYSIS OF INTERVIEWS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this study was to conduct a content analysis of interviews with African American music therapists effectively serving African American clients. The primary topics that were discussed in this study were (a) cultural awareness, (b) stigmas of therapy within the African American community, and (c) historical realities vs. popular myths. The content analysis used 6 research questions with 10 African American music therapists in the Southeastern, Mid-Atlantic, and Southwestern regions. There were multiple variables found among the respondents related to the themes of these interviews. These issues are discussed and illustrated with examples drawn from the interview transcripts.

DISS_description.DISS_title: A FRAMING ANALYSIS OF RIGHT-WING DOMESTIC TERRORISM INCIDENTS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Compared to Islamic terrorism, right-wing domestic terrorism is relatively understudied, even though right-wing domestic terrorism claims more lives in the United States and the frequency of these incidents is increasing (Jones, 2018; Jones, Doxsee, & Harrington, 2020). This study addressed the gap in knowledge of understanding how media outlets frame right-wing domestic terrorism in the initial days of coverage. Understanding how the media frames the issue of right-wing domestic terrorism is vital, as framing can influence how an audience comprehends an issue and what the possible solutions might be. To understand this media framing, this study employed a longitudinal qualitative and quantitative content analysis of right-wing domestic terrorism media framing in local and national newspapers. The use of these two methods allots both a micro and macro analysis and in turn a more well-rounded understanding of right-wing domestic terrorism media framing. The quantitative content analysis examined national and local newspaper coverage of right-wing domestic terrorism incidents and found several differences in framing between these outlets. The qualitative content analysis examined seven right-wing domestic terrorism incidents in national newspaper coverage and found twenty unique major frames. The frequency of use of these frames changed between incidents and a longitudinal trend of increasing frame usage was found. Differences in frame usage suggests that frames are competing for visibility and there is not one narrative utilized in a right-wing domestic terrorism context. This study represents the first large scale, multi-incident, analysis of right-wing domestic terrorism media framing and is a vital first step in understanding the media terrorism relationship within this context.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Relationship Between Reminding and Integration

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Animacy, Integration, Memory Facilitation, Memory for Change, Reminding

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Information that changes is often recalled worse than information that does not change, such that memory interference is observed (Anderson & Neely, 1996). However, studies using the A-B, A-D paradigm have revealed that when reminding occurs during the encoding of changed information and is recollected at test, it can result in memory facilitation, such that changed information is recalled better than control information that is only presented once (Wahlheim & Jacoby, 2013). One possibility is that reminding allows for memory integration, which in turn produces the facilitation observed in prior work. Memory integration allows us to make sense of new information in our daily lives, and has significant implications for the field of education (Bauer, Esposito, & Daly, 2020). Although reminding appears necessary for memory integration to occur, reminding alone does not appear sufficient. The aim of the present studies was to better understand the factors and mechanisms underpinning the relationship between reminding and integration. Although animacy status has appeared to be an important factor for integration in previous studies (Schreiner, Meiser, & Bröder, 2022), Experiment 1 found that animate and inanimate cue words did not differ in reminding during encoding, reminding recollection at test, nor in evidence of integration. Experiment 2 suggested that measuring reminding through mental imagery reports better captured integration relative to asking a direct question about reminding, and provided a new method of investigating the relationship between reminding and integration. Experiments 3 and 4 found that reminding occurred in an open-loop paradigm, but critically, found that an increased rate of reminding in that paradigm did not predict increased evidence for memory integration, and provided mixed evidence for a correlation between event structure awareness and memory integration. Taken together, the results of these experiments deepen the current understanding of the human memory system by providing support for the notion that reminding is necessary but not sufficient for memory integration, and providing new methods for investigating reminding and integration that can be used in new paradigms.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Project-based learning experiences of middle school teachers: Examining project design, management strategies, and implementation context

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: professional development, professional development, project-based learning

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study explores the project-based learning (PjbL) of middle school teachers by examining their instructional context and the project design and management strategies they used to implement PjbL. The significance of this study is to provide middle school teachers with greater perception, insight, and strategies about how the quality of their PjbL practice can be calibrated and improved. A purposeful sample of five middle school teachers across English Language Arts (ELA), mathematics, and career and technical education (CTE) courses participated. The research questions guiding this study were: Research Question 1. What are the contextual factors under which middle school teachers implement PjbL? Research Question 2. What design and management strategies do middle school teachers use to implement PjbL? The project design elements and teaching practices listed in the Gold Standard Project-based Learning model were used to describe each case. Evidence shows that all the elements and teaching practices listed in the Gold Standard Project-based Learning model appeared to some degree in each case. Three context-specific themes: curriculum, pedagogy, and structural, were also identified. Findings from this study contribute to the ongoing discussion of effective PjbL practice, illustrate the complexities of designing and managing PjbL, and can used to inform future research of PjbL.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Parent-Reported Levels of Anxiety in Children with Special Education Classifications

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Elementary school children with academic challenges are often provided special education services. These services are meant to support children in their academic goals, through either academic intervention (e.g., reading or math) or physical aids (e.g., extra test time, larger fonts). Being classified as eligible for receiving special education services has been shown to be associated with a child’s mental health. One potential outcome is higher levels of anxiety. Children worry about their academic disparity and about how they may be ostracized from their peers, given their label of requiring special education. All these factors could increase their risk for developing higher levels of anxiety. To explore associations of special education participation and anxiety in children, I used archival elementary grades follow up data from a larger intervention study conducted with children during preschool; the follow up outcome of interest is child anxiety symptoms as rated through parent report. The data were analyzed through three ANCOVAs to explore the relationship between special education classifications and anxiety levels. I found non-significant results between children receiving special education classifications of any kind on parent-reported anxiety levels. When I compared individual classifications clusters to no special education classifications, I found significant results between children who were classified as having a combination of physical and cognitive special education classifications on parent-reported anxiety levels. Lastly, I found non-significant results for the relation between the age children began receiving special education classifications and anxiety levels. All of this concludes in a complex picture of special education classifications on parent-reported anxiety levels. Further research is required to discover if special education classifications work as a protective factor or a risk factor for child anxiety levels.

DISS_description.DISS_title: EXCAVATIONS FROM 17TH AND 18TH-CENTURY HOUSES: A STUDY OF ARTIFACTS OF PERSONAL ADORNMENT AND DRESS FROM SPANISH COLONIAL MISSION SAN LUIS DE TALIMALI AND ST. AUGUSTINE HOUSEHOLDS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: archaeology, casta paintings, Florida archaeology, jewelry, personal adornment, Spanish colonial archaeology

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: An analysis of jewelry and other artifacts of personal adornment from the reconstructed house at the frontier mission San Luis (8LE4) in Tallahassee, FL and the Avero house (8SA7-5) in the capital of the La Florida colony, St. Augustine, FL gives archaeologists an example of what the climate of Spanish society may have looked like in an outer Spanish colony. By analyzing the archaeological record, paintings, and historical documentation, we may be able to understand how people maintained themselves, their appearance, and their calidad in colonial society.

DISS_description.DISS_title: REDUCED CELL SPREADING AND FORCE ON TALIN WITH ARP2/3 INHIBITION DOES NOT PREVENT YAP ACTIVATION

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Cells sense the mechanical properties of their environment through physical engagement and spreading, with high stiffness driving nuclear translocation of the mechanosensitive transcription factor YAP. Restriction of cell spread area or environmental stiffness both inhibit YAP activation and nuclear translocation. The Arp2/3 complex plays a critical role in cell spreading, protrusion, and migration. While YAP activation has been closely linked to cellular spreading, the specific role of the Arp2/3 complex in force buildup and YAP activation is unclear. To assess the role of Arp2/3 in this process, we measured cell spreading, YAP nuclear translocation, force on the adhesion adaptor protein Talin (FRET tension sensor), and extracellular forces (traction force microscopy, TFM) in 3T3 cells with and without inhibition of Arp2/3. The results indicate that YAP activation still occurs with reduced cell spreading. Interestingly, while actin de-branching resulted in decreased force on talin on stiff glass surfaces, relatively little change in average traction stress was observed on the softer TFM substrates. While cell spreading is a driver of YAP nuclear translocation, this is likely through indirect effects. Changes in cell spreading induced by Arp2/3 inhibition do not significantly perturb YAP activation. Additionally, this work provides evidence that focal adhesion and cytoskeletal forces are less direct regulators of YAP activation than previously thought.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Undergraduate Student Leadership Reflections in an Academic Innovation Center

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Academic Innovation Centers, Constructionism Leadership, Makerspaces, paraprofessionals, undergraduate leadership

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Academic innovation centers (AICs) are a new phenomenon that are being invested in by higher education institutions. As they are a new type of information center, Library and Information Science (LIS) researchers can revisit past LIS approaches in this new setting. Surveys of these centers have been investigated for their service offerings creating a nascent method of characterization. This LIS research explores this new research setting through the lens of the undergraduate student worker using narrative analysis methods. The library undergraduate worker has a limited depth of study within LIS research. This exploratory research repositions student workers’ agency to an elevated level for the understanding and development of academic innovation centers. These findings represent often silent voices of information center partnerships that bring added value to the higher education experience. This research highlights the developing perspective of undergraduate pre-professional leadership activities along with the theoretical basis of Constructionism Leadership.

DISS_description.DISS_title: LIQUID HELIUM TURBULENT PIPE FLOW AND MAGNETIC LEVITATION RESEARCH

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Liquid helium-4 undergoes a phase transition below about 2.17 K where it is called the superfluid (He II). He II is a non-classical fluid which is one of the very few macroscopic manifestation of the quantum mechanics. He II entails several bizarre properties including an extremely low kinematic viscosity. Due to this, He II has been proposed as an exceptional working fluid for turbulence research. The primary goal of the current thesis is to design a pioneering experiments to investigate the possibility and potential non-classical behavior of a law of the wall scaling in turbulent He II pipe flow. Here we report assembling a 5-m long He II flow facility so-called Liquid Helium Flow Visualization Facility which can generate He II turbulent flows with Reynolds numbers ($Re$) larger than a million. Inside an optically-accessible square flow pipe of $2 \times 2$ cm$^2$ cross-section, we generate fully-turbulent He II forced flows using an automated bellows-linear actuator pump. We also report the incorporation of a quantitative flow visualization technique called molecular tagging velocimetry (MTV) using metastable triplet helium molecules as tracers. This visualization technique is based on a combination of a femtosecond laser-field ionization together with a 905-nm laser-induced fluorescence scheme to generate and illuminate the metastable helium molecules, respectively. We have designed and implemented a novel optical system to guide and satisfy the optical criteria for visualization of He II. Using this one-of-a-kind facility, we report the first quantitative flow visualization study of the law of the wall in He II turbulent pipe flow. We acquire the mean velocity profile near the wall region using a robust image processing algorithm, specifically developed for the type of images we acquire in our flow pipe and we compare it with the existing data in classical fluid research. Our data shows the existence of a logarithmic profile of ``the near-wall mean velocity profile in turbulent pipe flow (NVP) in He II". By fitting the velocity profile using the law of the wall formula, we determined the two fitting coefficients including the von K\'arm\'an coefficient $\kappa$ and the additive constant $B$ in He II. We also conducted a comprehensive uncertainty analysis of data to evaluate the associated error. It turns out $\kappa=0.160\pm 0.015$ and $\kappa=0.154\pm 0.010$, and $B=-23.2\pm 0.4$ and $B=-24.0\pm 0.4$ for $Re_D=1.01\times 10^6$ and $Re_D=1.21\times 10^6$, respectively. On the other hand, the values of these two constants in classical turbulent pipe flow are determined about $\kappa=(0.37-0.42)$ and $B=(4-6)$. This significant difference suggests that the non-classical properties of He II affects the velocity profile in extremely high $Re$ He II pipe flow. This deviation from classical turbulence is of great significance for future numerical research as well as engineering designs of the He II pipe systems.

DISS_description.DISS_title: INVESTIGATING USABILITY OF THE SMARTWATCH AS AN EVERYDAY PROSPECTIVE MEMORY AID FOR OLDER ADULTS WITH AND WITHOUT COGNITIVE IMPAIRMENT

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: assistive technology, cognitive impairment, older adult, prospective memory, smartwatch

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Prospective memory, the ability to remember and carry out an intention in the future, is crucial for maintaining health, independence, and social connections. Wearable technologies, such as smartwatches, have the potential to serve as effective prospective memory aids, but little is known about how older adults, particularly those with cognitive impairment, might interact with such devices. This study aimed to 1) understand the types of challenges older adults with a diverse range of cognitive abilities experience when using a smartwatch, and 2) gain an initial understanding of the potential for smartwatches to serve as a prospective memory aid for this population. Participants included 27 older adults (age 60+) with normal cognitive functioning and those with cognitive impairment due to mild cognitive impairment (MCI), traumatic brain injury (TBI), or post-stroke cognitive impairment (PSCI). Participants were asked to wear a smartwatch and use its reminder notifications to remember to complete a daily automated telephone survey for 10 days. Half of the participants were first asked to use their usual memory strategies without the smartwatch to remember to complete the same daily survey for 10 days. Participants completed an initial interview consisting of demographic, neuropsychological, and technology acceptance measures, and a final interview consisting of usability measures. Participants gave relatively low usability ratings for the smartwatches overall and reported a variety of challenges. The smartwatches did not appear to significantly help or hurt participants’ abilities to remember to complete the daily survey. Participants’ perceptions of their memory were significantly associated with their perceived usefulness of the smartwatches, suggesting that perceived memory challenges may play an important role in the adoption of smartwatches. Results suggest that the smartwatches used in the present study may not be the best fit for providing prospective memory support and can inform the development of future efficacy tests and interventions involving smartwatches.

DISS_description.DISS_title: HEALTHCARE STEREOTYPE THREAT AND LGBT WELL-BEING ACROSS THE LIFE COURSE

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Cohort Differences, Healthcare Stereotype Threat, LGBTQ, Psychological Distress, Self-rated Health

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Sexual and gender minorities (i.e., gay men, lesbians, bisexuals, trans people) (SGMs) have experienced both social and legal progressive change over the last 50 years. However, this group still reports worse health outcomes and healthcare experiences, compared to heterosexuals (Fingerhut and Abdou 2017; Fredriksen-Goldsen et al. 2013). An innovative survey instrument that applies stereotype threat to the healthcare setting (e.g., healthcare stereotype threat, HCST) offers a new avenue to detail these disparities and uncover potential means of mitigation. Stereotype threat is the fear of confirming negative stereotypes about one’s social group (Steele and Aronson 1996). HCST expands the construct to also include the fear of being negatively judged, evaluated, or diagnosed because of one’s SGM status (Abdou and Fingerhut 2014). Work on HCST shows it has significant effects for sexual minorities’ well-being (Fingerhut et al. 2021) and variations exist across age (Abdou et al. 2016). However, previous work is limited in several aspects.

First, it is unknown how and if HCST retains its significant adverse effect on well-being while considering more established health factors such as everyday discrimination and experiencing stigma. Second, the extant literature currently treats SGMs as a monolith by ignoring how HCST effects can differ across SGM groups and across birth cohorts. Third, there is currently no literature that details how HCST is associated with the well-being of trans people. Guided by previous literature, this dissertation investigates three main research questions to address these gaps: (1) How does the inclusion of discrimination and stigma influence HCST’s association on well-being?; (2) How does the effect of HCST on well-being vary across SGM groups?; (3) What moderating effects does birth cohort have on the association between HCST and well-being.

To explore these questions, I used two national probability datasets that I harmonized: Generations and Transpop. Both of these dataset are the first of their kind to have national probability samples focusing on SGM status. These data are also the first of their kind that capture representative groups of SGMs across three birth cohorts: young (18 to 27 years old), middle-aged (32 to 43 years old), and older (50-60 years old).

Results from Study #1 showed evidence that HCST is a unique health factor and that its effects significantly vary across SGM groups. Examining how HCST’s association performed with the inclusion of everyday discrimination and stigma shows that HCST retains a significant association on self-rated health and psychological distress, which supports that HCST is a unique, viable, and useful tool to understand health disparities SGMs experience. Second, Study #1 shows how trans people tended to report significantly worse outcomes when HCST was high compared to gay men reporting the same level. This result shows the importance of including trans people in future analyses and examining inter-group differences. Results from Study #2 highlighted variations of HCST effects on well-being across birth cohorts and further highlighted a heightened plight trans people face. Standardized effects of HCST on self-rated health show worse effects for older lesbians and older bisexuals while the effect is similar for young and older gay men. Middle-aged trans people’s self-rated health suffered significantly more so than young trans people’s. HCST emerged to hold a more severe effect on the psychological distress of the older cohort as their distress were significantly higher than their younger counterparts, regardless of SGM group. This latter trend also emerged for trans people compared to gay men in the young and middle-age cohorts for self-rated health and for the young and older cohorts for psychological distress. In these cases, trans people reported worse outcomes than gay men when both groups were reporting the same level of HCST.

This dissertation contributes to scholarship in many ways such as using two nationally-probability samples of SGMs in the US, exploring differences within the SGM groups, and including transgender people. And, known to this author, the first cohort differences tests of HCST on well-being for SGMs. The dissertation breaks new ground also in testing how HCST as a measure performs compared to more established health factors, which highlights a new avenue in studying health disparities. Finally, these results have several implications for informing future work on health disparities, beyond SGMs, and with informing interventions and policy change to mitigate this process.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Online sojourner communities: What can sojourners learn from them and do they aid cultural adaptation?

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: cross-cultural adaptation, expat, Facebook groups, online sojourner communities, sojourners, South Korea

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Sojourners, people who live outside their home countries, experience inevitable hardships when they separate from their home countries and live in new cultures. These hardships are collectively known as acculturative stress (Spradley & Phillips, 1972). To deal with acculturative stress, some sojourners seek information and social support from other sojourners in online sojourner communities (Oh & Butler, 2019; Ong & Ward, 2005). Sojourners have different knowledge needs throughout their sojourns, but it is unclear much they learn from participating in online sojourner communities and how useful this information is (Yoon & Chung, 2017). This study explores the information that sojourners need to adapt to life in their host countries during each stage of their sojourners and how effectively information they learn through participating in online sojourner communities. Though some researchers have focused on how sojourners benefit from online sojourner community participation, other researchers have had concerns. Researchers have found that long-term, extensive contact with other sojourners from the same country, termed co-nationals, is associated with poor cultural adaptation to the host country (Kim, 2001; Lim & Pham, 2016). In a meta-analysis of 76 studies about international students, Bender et al. (2019) found that “only support from mixed sources (i.e., not distinguishing between internationals, host, or co-nationals) is associated with a stronger effect of social support than support from co-nationals or fellow international students (compared with support from host sources)" (p. 827). Lim & Pham (2016) argued that sojourners could become so invested in online sojourner communities and their families in their home country that they have no free time to explore the host country and its culture. However, another study suggested that long-term contact with co-nationals could benefit sojourners' cultural adaptation (Cao & Zhang, 2012). This study explored the relationship between online sojourner community usage and cross-cultural adaptation. Additionally, it explored the benefits and drawbacks of participating in online sojourner communities. A convergent mixed methods research design using surveys and interviews guided this study. The surveys had qualitative questions, two quantitative psychological scales to assess cross-cultural adaptation, and one quantitative scale to assess Facebook usage. In keeping with Creswell & Creswell (2018)’s research methods, the qualitative interviews provided depth and explanations for quantitative findings from the survey. 160 sojourners currently living in South Korea completed the survey. Eight participants participated in the qualitative interviews through Zoom to investigate what sojourners gain from participating in an online sojourner community. This study found 25 common topics that sojourners must learn to adapt successfully to life in their host countries. As Yoon & Chung (2017) found, these needs varied by their sojourning phases. During the settling stage, Korean language learning/translation and banking/finance/insurance are followed closely by Korean rules/regulations/law, healthcare, and employment/work-related issues. During the established stage, overall reported needs increased by 19%. Most needs remained steady or had modest increases between phases, with few exceptions. Needs like automotive service/repair, childcare, and housing, had large increases between phases. Only one need had a sizable decrease between phases; Korean language learning/translation declined by 10% between phases. Participants reported the topics they learned about through participating in online sojourner communities. The most common topics they learned during their established phases were visa-related issues, Korean rules/regulations/law, employment/work-related issues, and groceries/dining. Participants also ranked the usefulness of the topics they learned about. The most valuable things they learned were employment/work-related issues, visa-related issues, childcare, groceries/dining, and Korean rules/regulations/law. Though childcare was a less common need, those with children found the information especially useful. Despite the information that sojourners exchange, there was no significant relationship between either of Demes & Geeraert (2014)’s cross-cultural adaptation scales and Facebook Sojourner Community Intensity Scale, an adaptation of Ellison et al. (2007)’s Facebook Intensity Scale. This study uncovered additional positives about participating in online sojourner communities. The communities provide socio-emotional support through fostering friendship, commiseration, and familial relationship support. Sojourners often organize and help foster offline events and can help sojourners establish connections to the host country. Sojourners generally regard the information in online sojourner communities as more timely, accurate, and accessible than official online sources. The communities also helped working sojourners with professional development and special lifestyle needs. However, there are also considerable drawbacks to participating in online sojourner communities. Negativity is a constant problem in many communities, discouraging some sojourners from participating. Inactive communities were more prone to inaccurate and outdated information. Tempers can flare, and arguments can occur in some communities. Repetitive low-effort questions can be a source of annoyance for long-established sojourners.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Impact of Political Trust, Privatization, and Foreign Aid on Immigration-related Attitudes

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The primary objective of this dissertation is to examine how attitudes towards immigration are affected by individuals beliefs about three actors: receiving-country governments, foreign aid donors, and immigration service contractors. I examine the impact political trust has on the willingness of individuals threatened by immigration to decide for greater restrictions on immigration, ﬁnding for an eﬀect that is conditional on which type of governmental actor is made salient to respondents. I also examine how the increasing presence of private contractors in the provision of immigration services in the U.S. impacts attitudes of the immigration regime’s legitimacy abroad. I ﬁnd that legitimacy is impacted by privatization but might depend on which type of functions are delegated to private actors. Finally, I look at the eﬀect of foreign aid on attitudes towards immigrants from donor countries and political support for increased immigration from donor countries. Using both observational and novel survey data, this collection of studies aims to provide the public opinion literature on immigration with a better understanding of how attitudes towards three major actors in immigration can inﬂuence subsequent policy and social attitudes.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Research On Effective Treatment of High-Risk Antenatal Population Experiencing Fetal Death: Implications for Music Therapy

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Antenatal Care, Fetal Death, Music Therapy

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this master’s thesis was to provide a literature-based summary of high-risk antenatal populations experiencing fetal death and the implications for music therapists providing support with this population. An overview of current treatment options and measures of effectiveness was discussed along with an overview of mental health considerations. Finally, implications for music therapists were discussed along with proposed music therapy interventions.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Population Genetics Model Extensions: Including Indels, Quality Scores, and a Spatial Domain

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Fixation, Indels, Maximum Likelihood, Population Genetics, Quality Scores, Wave of Advance

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Due to the large variance in the stochastic nature of evolution and DNA, it can be difficult to be sure that inferences that use genetical data are perfectly correct. However, as we incorporate more data into our analysis then the confidence of our inferences increases. I investigate the inclusion of 3 types of data that are typically ignored. The use of deletions and insertions in the maximum likelihood calculations of trees is investigated as well as using the quality scores in those same calculations. I show that including this data increases the probability of the true evolutionary tree being the same tree that a maximum likelihood method will infer. I also investigate the effects a geographically continuous population has on the genetical patterns and rates of fixation and timing of fixation, and how those rates compare to panmictic models, which ignore spatial structure.

Typically, Maximum likelihood techniques treat gaps in genetic data as unknown values. There have been a few attempts to build maximum likelihood techniques that include insertion and deletion processes, but these are usually very computationally expensive and infeasible in most cases. A Poisson Indel Process (PIP) has been developed, which reduces the theoretical computation of the likelihood calculations. I show how this method's computational cost can be decreased even further. I also show that it provides slightly more accurate inferences.

All data gathering techniques introduce some sort of error. DNA sequencers quantify the confidence the program has in each nucleotide with a quality score. These quality scores represent the probability that the sequencer misclassified the nucleotide in question. Most Maximum likelihood techniques ignore these quality scores. At times when the scores are really low that data will be thrown out. I show how to incorporate these quality scores into a maximum likelihood calculation. This requires an adjustment to the traditional conversion of nucleotide data into numerical data into a more realistic biological and mathematical conversion.

Modelling the spatial structure populations are often constrained to has proved to be difficult. There are infinite types of structure that can be imposed by a landscape, each structure having a different effect on the dynamics of the population. I investigate how a continuous landscape with individuals how can disperse only a finite distance affects how quickly new alleles spread through the population. The spread of neutral alleles is shown to be independent of population density. The expected probability and time to fixation are examined and shown to be affect by both the size and shape of the geographical area and the population density.

The rate of spread for advantageous alleles is dependent on the population density, with diminishing returns as population density increases. The probability of fixation is only slightly dependent upon population density, it is mostly dependent upon selective advantage, but the expected time to fixation is heavily dependent on population density and geographical area.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Chromosomal passenger complex: Regulation and function in the cell cycle in budding yeast

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Accurate chromosome segregation is vital to maintain genomic integrity. Chromosome missegregation, or aneuploidy, contributes to cancer development and conditions like down syndrome (Trisomy 21). Chromosomes are attached to microtubules during mitosis through centromere-localized kinetochores, and accurate chromosome segregation requires establishment of chromosome bipolar attachment. As a result of bipolar attachment, tension is generated across sister kinetochores. Failure in this process activates the spindle assembly checkpoint (SAC) to prevent anaphase entry and allow for correction of attachments errors. In contrast, tension generation is believed to silence the SAC for anaphase onset. One key regulator of the SAC is the conserved chromosomal passenger complex (CPC), composed of Ipl1 kinase, Sli15, Bir1, and Nbl1 in budding yeast. The CPC localizes to the kinetochore/centromere before anaphase entry. Kinetochore protein Ndc80 is one Ipl1 substrate, and its phosphorylation destabilizes kinetochore-microtubule interaction to promote error correction. After anaphase onset, the CPC is removed from the kinetochore/centromere and relocates to the spindle, where it assists in spindle stability. Meanwhile, Ipl1-dependent Ndc80 phosphorylation is reversed, but the phosphatase responsible for this reversal is unknown. In budding yeast, the phosphatase Cdc14 becomes active after anaphase onset and dephosphorylates Fin1, a regulatory subunit of protein phosphatase 1 (PP1). Fin1 dephosphorylation allows kinetochore recruitment of Fin1-PP1. In this work, we show that kinetochore recruitment of Fin1-PP1 triggers the removal of the SAC proteins Bub1/Bub3. Furthermore, Fin1-PP1 partially dephosphorylates Ndc80, which promotes kinetochore dissociation of Bub1/Bub3. In addition, phospho-deficient ndc80 mutants causes viability loss in response to syntelic chromosome attachment, wherein sister kinetochores are attached by microtubules from the same spindle pole, indicating the importance of timely Fin1-PP1 kinetochore localization in checkpoint regulation. Multiple mechanisms regulate CPC kinetochore/centromere localization. A main driver for localization is Sli15 phosphorylation by both cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) and Ipl1 kinases. After anaphase onset, Sli15 is dephosphorylated, which triggers CPC translocation to anaphase spindle. Active Cdc14 reverses CDK-imposed Sli15 phosphorylation, but it is currently unclear which phosphatase reverses Ipl1-imposed Sli15 phosphorylation. Here we show that Fin1-PP1 partially reverses Sli15 phosphorylation. Interestingly, premature Fin1 kinetochore localization is sufficient to promote both CPC dissociation from the kinetochore/centromere in metaphase and CPC spindle association in anaphase. In addition, premature Fin1-kinetochore localization or phospho-deficient sli15 mutants result in SAC defects in response to tensionless attachments. These results indicate that Fin1-PP1 reverses Sli15 phosphorylation imposed by Ipl1 to promote CPC translocation in anaphase. The tension checkpoint is a subset of the SAC that prevents anaphase onset in response to tensionless attachments. In response to tension defects, Ipl1 kinase phosphorylates the kinetochore protein Dam1 to prevent anaphae onset. Budding yeast Cin8 is a kinesin-5 motor protein, and its synthetic lethality with SAC mutants indicates the role of Cin8 in accurate chromosome attachment. To study the function of Cin8 in chromosome attachment, we constructed an auxin-inducible degron (AID) mutant, cin8-AID. With this conditional mutant, we show that cells lacking Cin8 arrest in metaphase due to unseparated spindle pole bodies. This metaphase arrest depends on the SAC as well as Dam1 phosphorylation by Ipl1 kinase. In cells expressing phospho-deficient dam1-3A, the metaphase arrest induced by Cin8 depletion is abolished, causing chromosome missegregation. These results support the conclusion that the cell cycle delay in cin8 mutants is a result of tensionless chromsome attachments. Because of the critical role of CPC in chromosome bipolar attachment, its kinetochore/centromere localization must be tightly regulated during cell cycle. SUMOylation is a post-translational modification, wherein SUMO (Small Ubiquitin-like Modifier) proteins are covalently attached to other proteins. SUMOylation has been shown to promote protein subcellular localization through the interacteion between SUMO and SUMO-interacting motifs (SIMs). This interaction facilitates formation of molecular condensates through liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS). On the other hand, formation of SUMO chains (polySUMOylation) can induce condensate disassembly by triggering a series downstream events, including ubiquitination by SUMO-dependent Ubiquitin ligases (STUbLs) and extraction by Cdc48 segregase. In mammalian cells, the CPC was shown to be enriched at kinetochores through LLPS. A recent work indicates that CPC components Bir1 is SUMOylated. One attractive idea is that CPC SUMOylation promotes it kinetochores localization, while polySUMOylation triggers CPC kinetochore delocalization for its translocation. In this work, we show that Bir1 phosphorylation is cell cycle regulated, and the absence of STUbL delays Bir1 dephosphorylation. Moreover, depletion of SUMO protease, Ulp2, increases Bir1 SUMOylation Interestingly, inducing polySUMOylation prevents proper CPC kinetochore localization in metaphase. These preliminary results support the idea that Bir1 SUMOylation may regulate Bir1 phosphorylation and CPC localization.

DISS_description.DISS_title: How to Design for People in Space: Factors Influencing Astronauts' Psychological Well-being during Long-term Space Travel

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: astronaut, interior design, perceptions, space travel, spacecraft, well-being

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this study was to investigate the effects of isolated and confined spacecraft environments on astronauts' psychological well-being with the aim to develop innovative strategies to mitigate senses of stress and anxiety in spacecrafts. Specifically, the author identified the features of spacecraft interior environments that negatively or positively affected astronauts’ perceptions of the environment and stress levels, including the size of spacecraft, orientation and layout, color, and presence of portholes. Space travel has been a longtime aspiration of humans. In historical terms, we only recently started exploring outer frontiers of Earth and planning for a distinct possibility to travel to neighboring Mars. During long-term space travel, astronauts may experience high levels of stress and anxiety, which may affect their well-being, create tension between crew members, and complicate the completion of tasks, ultimately leading to mission failure. The most critical issues related to astronauts' psychological well-being are physical isolation, stresses working and living in a hostile environment where a simple mistake can result in severe injuries or death, necessity to share workspaces and living quarters with other crew members resulting in limited privacy and personal space, and fatigue due to packed schedules. Two theoretical frameworks discussed in Chapter 2 of this thesis identify the specific aspects of the physical environment and psychological climate aboard spacecraft needed to maintain astronauts’ well-being: the Self-Determination Theory (Goemaere et al., 2019; Ryan et al., 2014) and the framework for relating crew member performance measures to spacecraft design and operations (Fanchiang et al., 2020), referred to as the Crew Member Performance Framework in this research.The interior design of spacecraft environments is essential to support not only the lives of astronauts but to help them with successful performance of work-related tasks, activities, and communication, enable physical mobility, and provide a supportive environment for crew socialization, recreation, and rest. The data for this qualitative ethnographic study was gathered from three different sources: publicly accessible astronauts journals and books, spacecraft schematics, and photo and video materials. The research focused on the analysis of the interior environment of the International Space Station, which has been continually operating and hosting astronaut crews since November of 2000. The data was analyzed using DeDoose qualitative coding software to identify thirty-two emerging themes over five major categories that characterize spacecraft interior environments: microgravity, workday, psychological health, design features, and other issues. A close examination of these categories indicates that module functionality, safety details, together with size, wayfinding and orientation, comfort and privacy features, incorporation of portholes, and color are the characteristics of spacecraft interior environments that affect astronauts’ overall psychological well-being and stress levels most. In the programming phase, the researcher analyzed historic spacecraft schematics to determine the potentially most effective design solutions for the project portion of this thesis, the renovation of the International Space Station. These results can be utilized by spacecraft engineers, architects, and interior designers to serve the needs of astronauts by supporting their psychological well-being and enhancing their experience onboard spacecraft during long-term space travel.

DISS_description.DISS_title: INVESTIGATING THEORIES OF THE TESTING EFFECT: ASSESSING THE UNDERLYING ASSUMPTIONS AND MECHANISMS OF THE EPISODIC CONTEXT THEORY AND THE DUAL MEMORY MODEL

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Dual Memory Model, Episodic Context Theory, Memory, Posttesting, Retrieval Practice, The Testing Effect

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: When compared to restudy, a practice test results in greater final test recall, a phenomenon known as the testing effect, and has been replicated across hundreds of experiments (Rowland, 2014; Adesope et al., 2017); however, consistent theoretical explanations for the benefits of testing remain elusive. I investigated the underlying assumptions for two prominent theories of the testing effect, the episodic context theory (Karpicke et al., 2014) and the dual memory model (Rickard & Pan, 2018). Across four experiments (combined n = 426) I contrasted the predictions of the theories regarding the specificity of learning (Experiments 1 and 2), attempted to manipulate context updating as proposed by the episodic context theory in a restudy condition using instructions to retrieve the acquisition phase context during the practice phase (Experiment 3), and attempted to manipulate the number of memory traces the dual memory model proposes are created during the practice phase using pretesting (Experiment 4). Across these experiments I found no support for the episodic context theory assumption that context updating results in greater retrieval on a final test. In contrast, I found conflicting evidence for the dual memory model assumption that a second memory trace is created during a practice test. These experiments take an initial step toward behavioral tests of the core assumptions for two important models of the testing effect and reveal important directions for future research. Additionally, the results of Experiment 3 suggest a complex context change may be a potential boundary condition for the testing effect, which has important implications for education and learning.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Storied Interactions: Narrative Inquiry of Collaborative Object-Based Learning with Andean Textiles

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Cultural Heritage Objects, Interpretive Lens, Museum Training, Narrative Inquiry, Object-Based Learning, Visitor-Centered Curation

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this study was to explore the ways graduate students’ interpretive lenses manifested in reflective storytelling of their collaborative object-based learning (OBL) experiences with Andean textiles in the John and Mary Carter Collection. This occurred in the context of visitor-centered exhibition (VCE) development. Adapted Feminist Thinking Systems (Love & Villeneuve, 2017; Stephens, 2013) as an epistemological framework guided the development and implementation of this research project. The methodology of narrative inquiry (Clandinin, 2016; Clandinin and Connelly, 2000) recognized the complexity of student experiential stories as expressions of their unique voices. Five graduate students reflectively narrated their OBL and VCE experiences at Florida State University during a global pandemic. Student interpretive lenses during OBL activities showed the ways differences in their backgrounds and experiences contributed to their stories on the Andean textiles. The imaginative storytelling process provided scaffolding for participants to interpret novel OBL experiences with the textiles and generate creative ideas for VCE development. The dissonance between individual interpretive lenses and collaborative OBL influenced participant stories and the VCE narrative process. The VCE team members needed facilitative guidance with rationales on the relationships between object study, object stories, object research, and different types of interpretive narratives for the VCE plan. Collaborative OBL and VCE activities constituted paradoxical events. Students acknowledged the importance of collaboration for VCE planning and museums. Participant interpretive lenses of OBL activities with Andean textiles for collaborative VCE development contributed to embodied stories of experiential museum training as aesthetic life-story narratives for future experiences.

DISS_description.DISS_title: CHILDHOOD TRAUMA SCREENING AND EARLY LITERACY SKILLS: PREDICTOR IMPORTANCE AND CLASSIFICATION ACCURACY OF CHILDHOOD TRAUMA MEASURES FOR EARLY IDENTIFICATION OF KINDERGARTENERS AT-RISK FOR POOR READING OUTCOMES

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Early Childhood Trauma, Intergenerational Trauma, Kindergarteners, Reading Outcomes, Trauma Screening, Virtual Learning Environments

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Early childhood traumatic experiences place children at-risk for social, emotional, and behavioral impairments that contribute to poor educational outcomes. There is an increasing awareness that children with early traumatic exposure may need supplemental supports for academic success. These supports may be presented in the form of individual-student or whole-school trauma-informed care models. Existing prevention models, such as Multi-Tiered Systems of Support (MTSS) or Trauma Informed Care (TIC), accommodate early screening of students’ skills and behaviors, however, there is a lack of consensus in the literature regarding how trauma is measured within school environments and at what age students should be screened for the effects of childhood trauma on their educational success. Using a dominance analysis and ROC Curve analysis, this dissertation examined the overall predictive validity of childhood trauma measurement to early literacy skills and the tradeoff in classification accuracy of the measurement of childhood trauma in the early identification of kindergarteners (n=145) engaging in virtual learning environments who are at-risk for poor early reading and language outcomes. Findings demonstrated that trauma was a significant predictor of reading outcomes but integrating student behaviors enhanced the classification accuracy of the traditional MTSS methods for identifying at-risk readers. Results from this study provided the first empirical link between trauma and reading outcomes in kindergarteners in virtual learning environments. Results can inform TIC and MTSS models of care and provide preliminary empirical support for Whole-Child Learning Models.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THE GENERAL APPEARANCE CONCERNS SCALE: DEVELOPMENT OF A MODEL-BASED TRANSDIAGNOSTIC MEASURE USING ITEM-RESPONSE THEORY

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: appearance concerns, bifactor model, item response theory (IRT), transdiagnostic

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Physical appearance concerns are a prominent feature of several psychiatric disorders including body dysmorphic disorder, eating disorders, and social anxiety disorder, and a growing body of research suggests that appearance concerns may have important utility as a transdiagnostic construct. However, self-report measures of this individual difference characteristic have been developed primarily within disorder-specific frameworks, in contrast with emerging dimensional models which seek to identify and investigate shared factors impacting systematic comorbidity. The lack of a psychometrically sound, transdiagnostic measure of appearance concerns constitutes a major limitation of ongoing work in this area that hinders the ability of researchers to integrate results across studies and samples. The aim of the current work was to develop and validate an efficient scale measure of physical appearance concerns for use in future studies investigating its role in different psychiatric conditions and their systematic comorbidity. We utilized item response theory and structural modeling methods to identify a subset of items from three widely used appearance-related scale measures with optimal measurement properties for indexing variations in general appearance concerns - resulting in a brief, nine-item General Appearance Concerns Scale (GACS). This new scale showed effective coverage of the general appearance concerns trait continuum, a unidimensional structure and excellent internal consistency, and evidence of criterion-related validity. Results support the GACS as an effective instrument for assessing symptoms within the domain of appearance concerns and a vehicle for pursuing systematic research on physical appearance concerns as a transdiagnostic construct.

DISS_description.DISS_title: LOCALIZING THE GLOBAL: THE SHAKUHACHI'S PLACE IN "AMERICAN" CULTURE

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: anthropology, globalization, Japanese music, pedagogy, shakuhachi

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Concepts like cultural relativism, tradition, and authenticity warrants a more critical examination in an age where much of the world’s population has adopted a digital lifestyle that is always online. As a cultural artifact, the internet has become integrated with human interaction and the cultural impact of its convenience has been taken for granted—the effect the internet and mobile telephony continues to have on blurring boundaries between cultural appropriation and cultural appreciation is tremendous and deserves more critical introspection, dialogue, and discourse among scholarship within the field of humanities. This dissertation uses the lens of online shakuhachi study to not only explores the boundaries between cultural appropriation and cultural appreciation but also to bring forth a much-needed dialogue about the meaning of terms such as cultural relativism and tradition in an era of hypermediated technoculture. The combination of interlocution, observation, interpretation, and participation has revealed that the ethnographic encounters of shakuhachi in the United States are mostly represented by “non-native” shakuhachi musicians. The transmission of the shakuhachi tradition, and other similar cultures that have non-native participants, are contending with a more complicated notion of the “crisis of representation”—lineages of different types of shakuhachi traditions are being transmitted by non-native shakuhachi musicians.The internet and other media devises play a significant role in how the narrative of shakuhachi history is told—a popular trope in the historiography of the instrument is that “the shakuhachi is an ancient instrument of Zen.” By drawing on my experiences studying shakuhachi with dai-shihan (大師範, grandmaster) Michael Chikuzen (竹禅)Gould, I deconstruct the history of the instrument in an effort to understand why shakuhachi is still characterized through romanticized notions of Buddhist thought and imagery.

DISS_description.DISS_title: BIOMEDICAL ENTITY RELATION EXTRACTION FROM TEXT AND TRIANGULATION-BASED ITERATIVE CLOSEST POINTS ALGORITHM FOR GLOBAL PROTEIN SURFACE COMPARISON

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Biomedial literature usually contains cutting edge research results on biomedical entities, in particular the relation between them, for example the interaction between two proteins. However, the ever-increasing volume in the literature makes it impossible to humanly annotate them all, thus automatic extraction of these relations from literature has become more important. In this dissertation, we discuss three projects related to extract relations in biomedical text, as well as another project on protein surface matching. In the first project on extracting relations, we process protein-protein relations from protein-protein interaction databases and build a sentence level relation model using distance learning. This method uses bags to group predictions of all sentences related to an entity pair into a prediction on the entity pair itself. We show our performance on our own dataset. In the second project, we participated in the BioCreative VII challenge on text mining drug and chemical-protein interactions. For each sentence and entity pair in the sentence, we are asked to find the exact relationship type of the entity pair. We achieved 75% F1 score and placed the 8th out of 21 participants. In the last project, we participated in the LitCoin challenge. Here we focus on the the second part of the challenge, where the goal is to predict the exact relation type for biomedical entities of various types, including genes, diseases, cell lines, etc. We won the first place by achieving a 0.633 Jaccard score. In the protein surface matching project, we developed a fast program to calculate distances between protein surfaces using an algorithm that our group has published before.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Lord, Why Did You Make Me a Black Woman?: Examining the Intersection of Race and Gender for Black Women Senior-Level Leaders at Historically Black Colleges and Universities and Historically White Institutions

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Black women, gender, higher education, race, senior-level leadership

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The representation of Black women in senior leadership positions within higher education hovers at a dismal 5.8% (Wilder et al., 2013). Though Black women’s degree attainment has increased substantially in comparison to other racial groups (NCES, n.d.), they are not recruited and supported in these roles (Jackson & Harris, 2007), especially in both Historically Black Colleges and Universities and Historically White Institutions. Consequently, the women who are successful in obtaining administrative and executive positions share experiences that illuminate a system still plagued with sexism and racism (Cooper, 2020). Using Black Feminist Thought, Intersectionality, and Misogynoir as frameworks, as well as a critical narrative inquiry, I explored the intersection of race and gender for Black women in senior-level leadership roles at HBCUs and HWIs.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Aggregated Pulse Analysis: A New Framework for Shape-Driven Analysis of Bioacoustic Signals in the Time Domain

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Bioacoustics, Signal Processing, Time Series Analysis

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Bioacoustics has long been a vital source of knowledge in the life sciences. Bioacoustics provides us with an invaluable set of tools and insights to help us better understand how life interacts with one another and its environment. Traditional bioacoustic techniques have all drawn heavily from Signal Processing, itself a subfield of Electrical Engineering. Signal Processing techniques have allowed for unprecedented insight into the structure and makeup of these signals. They have also allowed us to better understand their information content and time-varying structure. However, much work remains to be done. Much of the information encoded in the frequency-domain representations analyzed by most traditional methods are also encoded in the time-domain shape of the signal itself. In this work, we present a new technique for analyzing bioacoustic signals using only the time-domain and the shapes of individual vocalization acts, called pulses. This method provides a new, simpler way of comparing vocalizations across individuals and populations.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Using a new implicit measure of automatic romantic partner preferences to predict romantic interest in speed-dating partners and satisfaction with subsequent relationships

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Close Relationships, Implicit Attitudes, Partner Preferences

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The Ideal Standards Model suggests that individuals should demonstrate more romantic interest in a potential partner and be more satisfied with an existing partner to the extent that the partner possesses the traits they desire (termed ideal-partner consistency). Further, evolutionary perspectives on mating suggest that individuals should possess varying degrees of desire for three critical partner traits – attractiveness-vitality, status-resources, and warmth-trustworthiness. While ideal-partner consistency on these traits has predicted satisfaction with existing partners in prior work, findings for interest in potential partners have been more mixed. This dissertation proposes that findings have been mixed because the self-report measures used in most prior work have failed to capture individuals’ automatic, gut-level preferences. Accordingly, I examined the extent to which ideal-partner consistency using (1) self-reported preferences for attractiveness, status, and warmth in a partner and (2) automatic preferences for these traits in a partner captured using a new implicit measure uniquely predicted interest in potential partners during a speed-dating event and satisfaction with relationships formed after the event. Ideal-partner consistency for self-reported preferences did predict more interest in potential partners for men and more satisfaction with current partners for both men and women, though greater consistency predicted less interest for women. Further, ideal-partner consistency for automatic preferences predicted more interest in potential partners among individuals with a short-term mating orientation, but surprisingly, less interest among those with a long-term mating orientation.
