Lastly, consistency for self-reported preferences generally predicted outcomes more strongly than did consistency for automatic preferences. These findings join some prior work in demonstrating that some of the preferences individuals report predict both the partners they later pursue and their later satisfaction with those relationships. These findings also may suggest that individuals do not allow their gut-level associations with certain traits to strongly guide them toward partners with these traits, nor do these associations affect their later relationship satisfaction. However, future work may benefit from re-examining these associations using a revised implicit task.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Dimensionality Tuning of Triplet Sensitizers for Triplet-Triplet Annihilation-Based Upconversion

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Photon upconversion (UC), especially through the process of triplet-triplet annihilation (TTA), is capable of combining two photons into one higher energy photon which could be captured in applications such as photovoltaics, photocatalysis, optogenetics, imaging and sensing, and many others. TTA-UC systems rely on spin-triplet states donated from a sensitizer material, which is commonly either an organometallic molecule or a semiconductor nanocrystal confined in three dimensions, typically referred to as a quantum dot. This dissertation encompasses a different approach to triplet sensitization specifically applied to TTA-UC. Semiconductor nanocrystals with quantum confinement relaxed in either one or two dimensions have unique properties endowed by their shape, size, and anisotropic nature, making them viable candidates for triplet sensitization. Chapter 3 explores CdTe nanorods, materials with two dimensions of quantum confinement, as potential triplet sensitizer materials in a red-to-blue TTA-UC scheme. TTA-UC is successfully observed in this system with a UC efficiency better or comparable to similar nanocrystal sensitized systems. Chapter 4 investigates the use of CdSe nanoplatelets, which are only quantum confined in their thickness. Here, the nanoplatelets are compared directly to quantum dots. Comparing the results of the nanoplatelet and quantum dot sensitized systems results in an interplay between the incident power threshold required for efficient TTA-UC and the UC efficiency, attributed to stacking of the nanoplatelets, which was shown to inhibit the performance of the nanoplatelet sensitized system. In Chapter 5, bulk semiconductors are explored as potential triplet sensitizers, through the use of bulk metal halide perovskites, which rely on no quantum confinement, and sensitize the annihilator molecule through a free charge mechanism. The performance of these systems is reliant on many factors, including the composition, fabrication method of the perovskite sensitizer, and the illumination time of the perovskite, which tunes its defect density. In summary, this dissertation looks beyond conventional semiconductor quantum dots as triplet sensitizer materials toward a new class of materials which include nanorods, nanoplatelets, and bulk semiconductors. In all cases, TTA-UC is successfully observed. However, the lasting relevance of these systems may rest on their ability to sensitize TTA-UC systems in the solid-state, which is a key development for their implementation into solid-state device applications such as photovoltaics. Bulk perovskite sensitized systems are already among the most efficient and useful solid-state triplet sensitizers, while nanorods and nanoplatelets could outperform existing solid-state nanocrystal sensitizers due to their improved exciton diffusion lengths upon self-assembly. These potential strategies and future developments toward improving TTA-UC are further discussed in Chapter 6, where we look toward the potentially bright future of TTA-UC, especially toward device-relevant applications.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Exploring the Relationship Between Student Engagement and Early Career Earnings in a Public University

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: economic returns, labor market outcomes, student engagement

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation examined the relationship between student engagement in college and subsequent employment status and early career earnings in a public university. This study sought to understand whether or not student academic and social experiences in college are related to post-baccalaureate early career earnings. The literature review explored human and social capital theories, related student development theories, and the economics of education as it relates to the earnings premium of postsecondary education. The study analyzed student data and explored the relationship between student experiences in college and subsequent employment status and early career earnings. The overall engagement measure dramatically increased the likelihood a student was employed within 6 months of graduation and was also positively related to early career earnings. Of the student engagement subscales, leadership and campus involvement and community service and philanthropy increased the likelihood a student was employed within 6 months of graduation. The leadership and campus involvement measure was also positively related to early career earnings in the full model, as well as in many of the conditional models for different student subpopulations. The international and global learning measure and the research and academic endeavors measure both had a negative relationship with the natural log of wages in the overall model and in many of the conditional models, plausibly due to increased engagement of students who may have been more inclined to enter into public service, social services, or the non-profit sector. Regarding the moderating relationships, the results suggested that the research and academic endeavors measure was more important to early career earnings for males than females, while the overall engagement measure and the community service and philanthropy measure were less important for STEM majors compared to non-STEM majors.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Sustaining Ethnicity, Expanding the Community, and Engaging Evangelicalism: Dutch-Americans in the Christian Reformed Church in North America, 1945-1995

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: American Religion, Canadian Religion, Dutch Reformed, Evangelicalism, Migration, Transnationalism

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Following the Second World War and through the end of the twentieth century, the Christian Reformed Church in North America experienced massive changes, beginning with unified institutional growth and a wave of new migration and ending with an internal struggle over the cultural changes occurring in North American culture. Rooted in Dutch migration, ethnicity, and Reformed theology, the denomination provides examples of how an established ethnic community adapted to new migrants, Christian youth adopted the cultural changes of the 1960s era, and a confessional religious community interacted with the rise of conservative white evangelicalism.

Part religious history and part ethnic history, this study attempts to merge the two historiographies to demonstrate how a community rooted in both religious faith and ethnic identity navigated the cultural and political landscape of the late twentieth century. Due to the binational character of the Christian Reformed Church, transcending the American/Canadian border, and the transnational nature of Dutch Reformed denominations during this period, this study engages with these changes outside of a strictly U.S. context.

Ultimately, I explore the development and meaning of community across time. Both the leaders and members of the Christian Reformed Church belonged to a specific community, one which plotted the direction of their lives and shaped their understanding of their local communities, their nation, and the broader world. I hope the reader will gain a sense of the world they created and developed and how it changed in relation to wider cultural transformations.

DISS_description.DISS_title: SELF-ARCHIVING ADOPTION IN LEGAL SCHOLARLY COMMUNICATION: ARE WE THERE YET?

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Law School, Open Access, Scholarly Communication, Self-archiving

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study examines the research and scholarship sharing and dissemination practices in an online environment among law school faculty. Guided by one of the most widely used technology usage and adoption models, Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology (UTAUT), it investigates law school professors’ attitudes and perceptions toward self-archiving and subsequent adoption and usage behavior through a qualitative research design of semi-structured interviews.

The findings indicate that participants generally have very positive attitudes towards Open Access (OA) and are in favor of supporting self-archiving and OA practice despite lacking knowledge of the subject. The majority of the participants use the Social Science Research Network (SSRN) for self-archiving which appears to be an “industry standard” in legal academia. Other platforms the participants choose to self-archive include institutional repositories, ResearchGate, Academia.edu, personal websites, institutional websites, and research consortium websites. Research confirms the accuracy of UTAUT’s concepts for understanding motivation factors for self-archiving among law school faculty; the findings further identify additional emerging concepts and also barriers and concerns law professors have regarding OA and self-archiving.

This study helps to fill the research gap and understand the self-archiving social phenomenon within an under-studied user group therefore supports libraries with improving current services, ensuring effective advocacy, and engaging potential initiatives regarding scholarly communication in the legal profession.

DISS_description.DISS_title: ON THE DYNAMICS OF THE ROSS GYRE: RELATIVE IMPORTANCE OF WIND, BUOYANCY, EDDIES, AND ANTARCTIC CIRCUMPOLAR CURRENT

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Dynamics, Gyre transport, Gyre Variablitity, Numerical modeling, Ross Gyre, Wind stress

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Formation of cold, dense waters south of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC) is one of the main drivers of the global overturning circulation, with major implications on the earth’s climate. A key region where the densest waters on earth are formed is the Ross Sea which is separated from the ACC by the Ross Gyre. The strength and variability of the Ross Gyre circulation impact the formation and export of dense water, and it is therefore important to understand its circulation and dynamics. Observations in the Ross Gyre are limited because of its remote location and the severe weather conditions. Furthermore, the ice cover limits the application of remote sensing techniques. Quantitative estimates of the gyre’s strength are difficult to obtain from hydrographic observations alone due to the limited sampling and the relatively weak stratification. In this dissertation, we use a combination of observations and modeling studies to a) provide an estimate of the strength and variability of the Ross Gyre transport and b) investigate the relative contributions of the wind and buoyancy forcing, eddies, and the presence of ACC to the Ross Gyre circulation. We find that the mean transport of the Ross Gyre can be as high as ~45 Sv, about twice of the typical estimate ~20 Sv reported in the literature. Sensitivity experiments to wind and buoyancy forcing, nonlinear terms, and the ACC were performed with a regional configuration of the Hybrid Coordinate Ocean Model (HYCOM). The numerical experiments show that the Ross Gyre, and its variability, are primarily wind-driven. The ACC is responsible for part of the recirculation. Buoyancy and nonlinearity/eddy do not appear to play a major role in the gyre dynamics.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Model Predictive Control of Morphing Wings using Embedded Geometrical Mapping Technique

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: airfoil fluttering, flow control, modal analysis, morphing surface

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Active flow control can achieve substantial performance gains and meet the challenges of next-generation air vehicles and energy harvesting devices. The use of active flow control techniques with the deflecting flap or morphing surfaces has been shown to be a viable path to regulating the flow-induced vibration of the foil. However, due to the complex nature of flow over morphing surfaces, all physical phenomena are intertwined, which prevents a clear understanding of the underlying flow physics and, therefore, a successful design of a controlling action to optimally modify them. In this research, fluid-structure interaction systems are modeled with a high-fidelity tightly-coupled numerical scheme. Specifically, an embedded geometrical description is used to model and track the dynamics of a foil with an actively deflecting flap. Through various analysis tools, including a geometrically-weighted modal analysis technique, mode competitions are observed between flow-induced and geometry-induced mechanisms, and the morphing structure is proven to be capable of regulating the fluid-structure interacting behaviors. Furthermore, an advanced network is developed to extract the transient transition of different modes in the fluid-structure interaction systems. With all the knowledge acquired through the modal analysis, an active flow control framework with the model predictive control theory is built to modulate the flow-induced flutter using morphing surfaces. The geometrically weighted dynamic-relevant modes are used to build surrogate models to achieve rapid model-based active control of complex systems. The proposed technique can create a systematic framework to advise substantial improvements in the functionality of next-generation systems through detailed investigations of fluid-structure interactions and provide insights into the effects of control design changes on the physical phenomena that drive the dynamic performance of these systems.

DISS_description.DISS_title: REGULATION OF PROTEASOME FUNCTION AND QUALITY CONTROL BY SHORT, FLEXIBLE MOTIFS IN THE ATPASE MOTOR

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: ATPases, Chaperone, Nas6, Proteasome, Proteolysis, Rpt3

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The 26S proteasome is the largest and most complicated chambered protease known. It is responsible for regulated degradation of proteins within all eukaryotic cells, and is essential for maintaining protein homeostasis. Disruptions to proteasome assembly, composition, or function cause or exacerbate numerous human diseases, including cancers, neurodegenerative disorders, and a family of autoimmune disorders. The proteasome is comprised of two major subcomplexes: the regulatory particle (RP) and the core particle (CP). Each serves distinct functions in degradation of substrate. The RP contains a ring of six AAA+ ATPase subunits that mechanically unfold substrate and translocate it into the proteolytic chamber of the CP, which houses the proteolytic active sites. The ATPase subunits are absolutely essential to proteasome function, as they served as both gatekeepers and guides for the diverse population of protein substrates that proteasomes must degrade to maintain proteostasis in a complex and crowded cellular environment. The unstructured C-termini of most proteasomal ATPase subunits dock into pockets in the surface of the barrel-shaped CP, tethering the RP to the CP and regulating substrate access to the proteolytic core. Furthermore, flexible pore-1 loops extend from each Rpt subunit into the central channel of the ATPase ring. These pore loops grip substrates and, via ATP-fueled movements, mechanically unfold and translocate them through the ATPase ring’s pore and into the CP for destruction. Given the exceptional size and complexity of the proteasome, the unstructured pore-1 loops and C-termini of the ATPase subunits exert disproportionally large impacts on its structure and function. Although some rudimentary analyses of their individual contributions have been performed, the myriad of ways in which they contribute to proteasome physiology remain very poorly understood. In this thesis, I describe my analyses of these key functional elements, which have challenged some aspects of the current model of substrate translocation by the proteasome, and have serendipitously revealed a potential quality control mechanism that disassembles proteasomes with compromised RP-CP interfaces. I discuss these findings in the context of our current understanding of proteasome function and quality control, and provide perspectives on new hypotheses and questions arising from my work.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The relationship between justice-involved adolescent mothers’ adverse childhood experiences and their children’s social and emotional development

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Adolescent Parenting, Adverse Childhood Experiences, Ecobiodevelopmental Framework, Juvenile Justice, Social and Emotional Development, Transgenerational

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study examined the transgenerational relationship between the prevalence of maternal childhood traumas for justice-involved adolescent mothers and her baby’s social and emotional risk by the age of 24 months. Two separate variables for the mother’s childhood trauma were used. The first of these variables came from the mother’s self-reported completion of the Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) Questionnaire. The second variable on the mother’s experiences of early adversity came from the same ACEs Questionnaire being completed by home visitors who worked with the mother/baby dyad scoring the questionnaire on the teen mother based on information that was shared by the teen and reviewing the teen’s records. Guided by the Ecobiodevelopmental Framework, the current study included epigenetic concepts in social science research to acknowledge the growing body of evidence that documents the complexity of contributing factors to infant social and emotional risk that go beyond the child’s significant relationships, environment, and community. The results indicated that the teen mother’s self-reported ACE score was not a significant predictor of the child’s social and emotional risk. The home visitor calculated ACE score, however, was a significant predictor of the child’s social and emotional risk. The gender of the child was also a significant predictor when controlling for the home visitor’s ACE score with boys being more likely to score at risk on the ASQ:SE.

DISS_description.DISS_title: BAYESIAN VARIABLE SELECTION FOR NON-GAUSSIAN DATA USING GLOBAL-LOCAL SHRINKAGE PRIORS AND THE MULTIVARAITE LOGIT-BETA DISTRIBUTION

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Variable selection methods have become an important and growing problem in Bayesian analysis. The literature on Bayesian variable selection methods tends to be applied to a single response- type, and more typically, a continuous response-type, where it is assumed that the data is Gaus- sian/symmetric. In this dissertation, we develop a novel global-local shrinkage prior in non- symmetric settings and multiple response-types settings by combining the perspectives of global- local shrinkage and the conjugate multivaraite distribution. In Chapter 2, we focus on the problem of variable selection when the data is possibly non- symmetric continuous-valued. We propose modeling continuous-valued data and the coefficient vector with the multivariate logit-beta (MLB) distribution. To perform variable selection in a Bayesian context we make use of shrinkage global-local priors to enforce sparsity. Specifically, they can be defined as a Gaussian scale mixture of a global shrinkage parameter and a local shrinkage parameter for a regression coefficient. We provide a technical discussion that illustrates that our use of the multivariate logit-beta distribution under a P ́olya-Gamma augmentation scheme has an explicit connection to a well-known global-local shrinkage method (i.e., the horseshoe prior) and extends it to possibly non-symmetric data. Moreover, our method can be implemented using an efficient block Gibbs sampler. Evidence of improvements in terms of mean squared error and variable selection as compared to the standard implementation of the horseshoe prior for skewed data settings is provided in simulated and real data examples. In Chapter 3, we direct our attention to the canonical variable selection problem in multiple response-types settings, where the observed dataset consists of multiple response-types (e.g., con- tinuous, count-valued, Bernoulli trials, etc.). We propose the same global-local shrinkage prior in Chapter 2 but for multiple response-types datasets. The implementation of our Bayesian variable selection method to such data types is straightforward given the fact that the multivariate logit-beta prior is the conjugate prior for several members from the natural exponential family of distributions, which leads to the binomial/beta and negative binomial/beta hierarchical models. Our proposed model not just allows the estimation and selection of independent regression coefficients, but also those of shared regression coefficients across-response-types, which can be used to explicitly model dependence in spatial and time-series settings. An efficient block Gibbs sampler is developed, which is found to be effective in obtaining accurate estimates and variable selection results in simulation studies and an analysis of public health and financial costs from natural disasters in the U.S.

DISS_description.DISS_title: CHARACTERISTICS OF LOW-LEVEL WIND SHEAR AND WIND PROFILER BASED ALERTING IN BALI, INDONESIA

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Low-level wind shear (LLWS) is one of the most common aviation hazards in both clear and bad weather conditions. Low-level wind shear is dangerous for landing or taking off activities because it can cause the aircraft to overshoot or undershoot. The short spatial and temporal scale of the occurrence of low-level wind shears and the lack of understanding of its characteristics cause the wind shear warnings can not to be carried out optimally. Therefore, this study aims to determine the characteristics of low-level wind shear that occurs in the Bali region, especially at Ngurah Rai International Airport. This study mainly uses two years of observational data from wind profilers to determine when LLWS occurs based on reports from pilots and wind shear warnings. This data will then also be used to calculate the value of the bulk Richardson number (Rb), which will be used to determine the condition of atmospheric stability during the LLWS. Additional data in the form of weather radar data and ERA5 will also be used to identify weather phenomena that can affect LLWS events. The results showed that LLWS in the Bali region most often occurred from morning to noon and in clear weather conditions. Moreover, the leading cause of LLWS is due to the inversion layer. The blocking of momentum transfer by the inversion layer usually causes LLWS to form at a threshold value of -0.25<Rb<0.1. Changes in the value of Rb and the formation of an inversion layer affect the location of the occurrence of LLWS, where most occur above the inversion layer or above the layer with a value of Rb<0.1. The calculation of the skill score shows a good result for the POD value of 0.7, FAR 0.27, CSI 0.55, and ETS 0.43, which indicates that LLWS can mostly occur if it is followed by a decrease in Rb in the threshold value range for four minutes and a change in wind direction and speed of 5 kt for ten minutes.

DISS_description.DISS_title: a heavenly steed, soaring across the skies

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: a heavenly steed, soaring across the skies is a two-movement work for orchestra. The title derives from the Chinese idiom. Chinese people use this idiom to describe a bold, imaginative, unconstrained style. This work intends to create an elevated and cohesive atmosphere connecting two superficially unrelated objects: sky lanterns as a symbol of fortune and the Forbidden City, a palace complex located in Peking (Beijing).The first movement is inspired by a story during the Three Kingdoms period (from 220 to 280 AD). A military strategist of one of the three kingdoms, Zhuge Liang (also known as Zhuge Kongming), invented the sky lantern. When the other Kingdom's army surrounded him in a town, he made sky lanterns to transmit messages to manage an escape from the siege, and he succeeded. Since then, the sky lantern has symbolized hope for success and fortune. Thus, this movement intends to deliver a prayer for hope. It begins with a slow-growing motive decorated by the ostinato in the high register to create a serene atmosphere. The middle section takes inspiration from Igor Stravinsky's "Infernal Dance" from “Firebird”, while reimagining it as if this music is written for a video game by featuring repetitive motives and limited polyphony. The driving and relentless section proceeds with the off-beat melodies and disturbs the previous tranquil section. Increased rhythmic pulses and an intense and dramatic atmosphere aims to throw the audience in a place as if a mighty force traps them. Along with the ascending stepwise motive truncated at the end of the middle section, the beginning slow-growing motive returns. The coda depicts sky lanterns flaming while flying to the sky. The second movement is about the Forbidden City. The Yongle emperor of the Ming Dynasty built this marvelous architecture. Since then, the emperors of all dynasties have lived in it. It gives people a sense of mystery and inaccessibility. This movement begins quickly with a short piano introduction accompanied by strings and woodwinds. After a dialogue among woodwind instruments, the main theme is presented in tutti. Influenced by the theme of the film music “The Last Emperor” composed by Ryuichi Sakamoto, the main theme of this movement features a four-note motif with pitches drawn from the pentatonic scale. This motif develops through variations of pitch and rhythmic durations. This movement also fused the features of film music, as it presents various moods through different distinctive musical characters. For example, the middle section uses the extensive virtuosic runs in woodwind parts interrupted by swells creating a sense of exhaustion; in contrast, a slow and lyrical dialogue between clarinet and piano relaxes the tensions between two climaxes, whereas the biggest climax (mm. 125-145) resembles a culmination of a soundtrack from an epic film. This movement aims to make the audience feel the magnificence of the Forbidden City.

DISS_description.DISS_title: MUSIC THERAPY STUDENTS’ EXPERIENCES WITH THEIR DISLIKED MUSIC AND THEIR THOUGHTS ABOUT USING THEIR DISLIKED MUSIC IN MUSIC THERAPY

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: There is much research on music preferences, responses to music, and music therapy using client-preferred music. Not as much research exists about the effects of music therapists’ preferred music, specifically their disliked music. The purpose of this study was to investigate music therapy students’ perceptions about their experiences with their disliked music and their opinions about using their disliked music in music therapy. A survey was sent out via email and social media, with a total of 20 undergraduate music therapy students responding. It included questions about having disliked music, listening frequency for disliked music, reactions to disliked music, preparation and use of disliked music in music therapy, and disliked music’s effect on relationships with clients. The survey consisted of 21 questions in total. In general, disliked music was listened to relatively infrequently, and participants perceived disliked music to produce negative emotional responses. Both similarities and differences were found between results for slightly disliked music and results for strongly disliked music. A notable difference was that most (n=9) music therapy students thought they should use slightly disliked music in music therapy but most (n=10) were unsure about using strongly disliked music. Two other differences between slightly and strongly disliked music were related to reactions to the music and the predicted effect on the relationship with clients. In light of the perceived negative effects of disliked music and other results from this study, music therapy students may benefit from discussion about possible responses they may have to disliked music and using disliked music in music therapy, including strategies that may facilitate its use.

DISS_description.DISS_title: FMRP MECHANISM OF CIRCUIT DEVELOPMENT AND DYNAMICS IN THE AUDITORY BRAINSTEM

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: afferent influence, brain development, critical period, Fragile X syndrome, hearing onset, synaptic maturation

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Fragile X syndrome (FXS) is a leading monogenetic cause of intellectual disability and autism. It is caused by transcriptional silencing of the FMR1 gene and the resultant loss of its product, Fragile X mental retardation protein (FMRP). Individuals with FXS display prominent sensory dysfunction including acoustic hyperactivity and compromised hearing in noise, which emerge at young ages. Animal studies have revealed maladaptive developmental events caused by the absence of FMRP, including delays in axonal and synaptic development as well as alterations in experience-dependent neuronal plasticity. These cellular abnormalities may underlie sensory processing deficits in FXS but show high regional- and time-specificity. Thus, whether and how individual developmental events contribute to the emergence and progress of circuit alterations are largely unknown. In addition, the precise sites of FMRP action in regulating these cellular and circuit pathophysiology remain elusive.In this dissertation, we dissected the role of FMRP in synaptic tonotopic development, afferent regulation of neuronal dynamics during developmental critical periods, and the association with the emergence of auditory processing problems by focusing on the auditory brainstem circuit using mouse and chicken as model organisms. In Chapter 2, we characterized the developmental distributions of key presynaptic neurotransmitter-releasing machinery in the mouse developing medial nucleus of the trapezoid body, a major auditory nucleus receiving excitatory inputs from the cochlear nucleus and serving as an inhibitory station for further processing. We identified novel tonotopic gradients of selective presynaptic proteins in immature auditory synapses in the first postnatal week, which gradually flattened before the onset of hearing (around postnatal day 12-14). In Fmr1 (human FMR1 homolog) knockout (KO) mice, a mouse model of FXS, progress to achieve the mature-like organization was selectively altered in some presynaptic proteins. These results provide a potential mechanism that may contribute to tonotopic differentiation of neurotransmission in the auditory system during normal and abnormal development. In Chapter 3, we examined how afferent deprivation affects the cellular FMRP dynamics and the association with neuronal reorganizations in the chicken cochlear nucleus, an auditory nucleus receiving afferent inputs from the cochlea. We observed rapid aggregation of FMRP immunoreactivity into large granular structures in a subset of neurons following afferent deprivation, and the persistent FMRP aggregation was associated with neuronal cell death in these neurons. In the surviving neurons, FMRP level was correlated with multiple types of neuronal responses and synaptic rearrangements, suggesting a potential role of FMRP in afferent-regulated neuronal dynamics. In Chapter 4, we investigated how loss of FMRP affects the afferent regulation of neuronal dynamics within a critical period in the mouse ventral cochlear nucleus (VCN), identified the relationship between the closure of the critical period and the onset of auditory experience, and determined a peripheral site of FMRP in regulating these events. We found that a critical period for VCN neuronal loss in response to deafferentation was preserved in Fmr1 KO mice, and within this critical period, the degree of neuronal loss was unchanged. However, the closure of the critical period for neuronal cell death was delayed and temporally coincidental with reduced hearing sensitivity in the absence of FMRP. Furthermore, selective deletion of FMRP expression in spiral ganglion neurons recapitulated the delay in VCN critical period closure, similar to Fmr1 KO mice. This study identified a novel involvement of cochlear FMRP in shaping the temporal features of neuronal critical periods in the brain, and highlighted a peripheral mechanism of neurodevelopmental pathogenesis.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Alternative tests and measures for between-study heterogeneity and time-lag bias in meta-analysis

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Meta-analysis is a widely used tool to combine research findings from multiple studies in many disciplines. In this thesis we develop novel methods to deal with two critical issues in systematic reviews and meta-analyses, such as assessing and testing between-study inconsistency and time-lag bias. The first part of this thesis concentrates on addressing the inconsistency between different studies' results. Such inconsistency could arise due to several factors, such as heterogeneity in baseline characteristics of individual studies' populations, different methods applied by research teams, and outlying effects of a few studies. In the current literature, the Q and I^2 statistics are commonly used to test for and quantify the between-study heterogeneity, respectively, but they are not powerful in many cases, particularly when the number of studies is small. This article propose alternative Q-like statistics for assessing inconsistency. We also propose a hybrid test to utilize the information and strength of all tests, and it is found to have relatively high power across multiple settings. We use simulated and real data to evaluate the performance of tests.

The second part of the thesis focuses on addressing the time-lag bias of studies. Time-lag bias occurs when studies with positive results are more likely to publish earlier than non-significant findings. The current literature uses the regression-based model to test the time-lag bias, but it is not powerful if the relationship between effect sizes and published time is not linear. This article proposes alternative measures and tests for assessing time-lag bias. Similar to the first part, We also propose a hybrid test to utilize the information and strength of all tests, and it is found to have relatively high power across multiple settings.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Facial Emotion Recognition Using Asymmetric Pyramidal Networks with Gradient Centralization and Learnable Preprocessors

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Facial expression recognition (FER) is a promising but challenging area of computer vision (CV).Many researchers have devoted significant resources to exploring FER in recent years, but an impediment remains: classifiers perform well on fine-resolution images but have difficulty recog- nizing in-the-wild human emotional states. In order to address the issue mentioned above, we introduced some novel designs and implemented them in neural networks. More specifically, we utilized an asymmetric pyramidal network (APNet) and employed multi-scale kernels instead of identical-size kernels. In addition, square kernels were replaced by square, horizontal, and vertical convolutions. This structure can increase the description ability of convolutional neural networks (CNN)and transfer multi-scale features between different layers. Grouped convolution was adopted as well. It reduces the training time and improves the model’s performance. Additionally, when training CNN, we applied gradient centralization to stochastic gradient descent with momentum (SGDMGC), which centralizes gradients to have zero mean and makes the training process more efficient and stable. Furthermore, the learnable preprocessor is placed before feeding initial images into the classification network. This structure generates images for a better recognition performance than high visual quality ones.

To verify the effectiveness of the proposed design, we used four of the most popular in-the-wildemotion datasets, FER-2013, FER+, RAF-DB, and SFEW, for our experiments. The results of our experiment and comparisons with state-of-the-art (SOTA) designs from others demonstrate that APNet with SGDMGC outperforms most of methods with a single model and even has comparable performance to methods with multiple models. By conducting an ablation study on our model, we found that removing any proposed technique or techniques would lead to performance degradation. The results thus prove that each design has boosted the performance of the proposed model on FER tasks. Next, simulation results from APNet with SGDMGC combined with the learnable preprocessors are displayed as well. This combination has a competitive performance compared with other SOTA model fusion methods.

DISS_description.DISS_title: A NEURAL PATHWAY UNDERLYING 14-3-3 DYSFUNCTION-INDUCED PSYCHOMOTOR BEHAVIOR

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Psychosis may arise from an altered modulation of the mesolimbic dopamine system. However, the source of upstream disturbance and the underlying neural circuitry remain unknown. It is generally agreed that genetic susceptibility contribute to the development of psychotic disorders. Among identified risk genes, several encodes multiple members of the 14-3-3 family of proteins. Previously, by transgenically expressing an isoform-independent 14-3-3 peptide inhibitor (difopein), we reported that 14-3-3 functional knockout mice exhibit psychomotor behavior and increased dopamine content levels in their striatum, both corresponding to human psychosis. To identify the key brain regions involved in the top-down control of specific schizophrenia-associated behaviors, we utilized an adeno-associated virus mediated difopein expression approach and found that region-specific inhibition of 14-3-3 proteins in the dorsal hippocampus CA1 (dCA1) alone is sufficient to induce psychosis-like behaviors in mice, including a novelty-induced hyperlocomotive activity associated with an increased neuronal activation in the hippocampus.While hippocampal hyperactivity is implicated in psychosis by both human and animal studies, whether it induces hyperdopaminergic state and the underlying neural circuitry remain elusive. Here, we further showed that 14-3-3 dysfunction in the dCA1 over-activates ventral tegmental area (VTA) dopaminergic neurons, and such over-activation is necessary in eliciting psychomotor behavior in mice. We demonstrated that such hippocampal dysregulation of the VTA during psychomotor behavior is dependent on an over-activation of the lateral septum (LS), given that inhibition of the LS attenuates over-activation of dopaminergic neurons and psychomotor behavior induced by 14-3-3 inhibition in the dCA1. Moreover, 14-3-3 inhibition-induced neuronal activations within the dCA1-LS-VTA pathway and psychomotor behavior can be reproduced by direct chemogenetic activation of LS-projecting dCA1 neurons. Collectively, these results suggest that 14-3-3 dysfunction in the dCA1 results in hippocampal hyperactivation which leads to psychomotor behavior via a dCA1-LS-VTA pathway.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Extraction of Association Structure by Latent Variables

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: In many biomedical studies, multiple sourced data with varied features are observed on the same subjects. Examples include longitudinal markers measured along with a time-to-event outcome of interest and multiset data with varied dimensions. To extract the association structure from the multi-sourced data poses great challenges. We present two Bayesian frameworks utilizing latent variables in order to provide solutions for these two specific data scenarios. For modeling longitudinal markers measured along with a time-to-event outcome, we develop a fully Bayesian joint longitudinal-survival model that uses a latent class structure to facilitate discovery of subgroups exhibiting distinct behavior, and our formulation incorporates estimation of the number of subgroups and offers enhanced flexibility with a subgroup-specific piecewise linear log baseline hazard. For modeling multiset data with varied dimensions, we propose a Bayesian framework that uses latent factors to decompose data into four conceptual parts: joint structure induced by the latent factors shared across all the sets, partial association structure induced by the latent factors shared by the associated subsets of the multiset data, individual structure induced by latent factors unique to each set, and noise. Our method enables flexible selection of latent factors and discovery of association structure as well as variable selection in the joint structure (and, if desired, in the partial association structure). For both methods, we show the ability and the performance by simulation, and use real data for demonstration.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Music Therapy in K-12 Schools: A descriptive analysis of music therapists' involvement in the IEP process and collaboration with other professionals

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Many music therapists provide school-based services of various forms throughout the country. Music therapy is eligible for inclusion in IEPs as a related service, but there has been little to no research into the rate at which music therapists are involved with IEP procedures. IEP teams must include a special educator, general educator, the student’s parent(s) or guardian(s), a school district representative, a school psychologist, and any related service that the student receives. How often do music therapists communicate and collaborate with these IEP team members? The researcher developed a 44-question survey to address these inquiries and distributed it to all MT-BCs who consented to receive research invitations. A total of 209 responses were included in analysis. Respondents practiced in all seven regions of the country and worked in a variety of school settings. Respondents had access to their students’ IEP information 82.8% of the time, and of those that had access to IEP information, 81.5% were satisfied with their level of IEP involvement. Most respondents communicated with IEP stakeholders on an as needed basis, reflecting the individuality and variability of needs that each student has. Limitations, implications for practice, and suggestions for future research are included.

DISS_description.DISS_title: A study on Loop Unrolling at the assembly code level

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Assembly optimizer, Compiler optimizations, Compilers, Innermost loop characteristics, Loop unrolling, Naive loop unrolling

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Loop unrolling is a compiler optimization that can improve the performance of applications without explicit intervention from programmers. In this study, we analyze how traditional loop unrolling techniques attempt to improve performance, and we propose new unrolling strategies that can unroll a greater number of loops than what is usually possible.

We perform loop unrolling using our assembly optimizer, which analyzes and optimizes code at the assembly level instead of at the compiler level. This gives us a different perspective of the code than what a typical compiler would have, as we do not concern ourselves with the source code or an intermediate language. We are free to make modifications at the instruction level, which allows us to optimize large sections of code that might otherwise be impossible to work on.

The optimizer collects statistics on the loops it unrolls, some of which are shown in our Results section. We ran our optimizer's unrolling algorithms on the SPEC 06 benchmark suite, and present both the statistics it generated as well as performance results from three different simulators. While performance gains are highly dependent on the application being optimized, we have shown it is possible to achieve considerable improvements by the use of loop unrolling.

DISS_description.DISS_title: College Bound Type Programs and Post-secondary Enrollment for Broward County Public Schools Students from Economically Challenged Communities

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: achievement gap, African American, Black Hispanic and low-income, college pathway programs, college type programs, post-secondary enrollment

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: There are widespread concerns about disparities in educational attainment in the United States. Unfortunately African American, Hispanic, Native American, and low-income Broward County Public Schools high school students participate in College Bound Type Programs at lower rates than students of other races and ethnicities. Many of these students are missing out on the significant advantages associated with college pathway programs such as higher post-secondary enrollment, persistence, and graduation rates. This quantitative outcomes study examined the associations with post-secondary enrollment of participating in College Bound Type Programs for Black and Hispanic Broward County Public Schools students who attended high schools in low-income communities. 3,620 students who entered ninth grade in 2013 were studied through graduation. Univariate, bivariate, and logistic regression analysis were utilized. Participation in College Bound Type Programs were found to be positively associated with post-secondary enrollment and 4-year college post-secondary enrollment respectively. These results highlight the positive outcomes associated with College Bound Type Program participation for this population. Policy makers and educators are urged to work together to start preparing parents and students as early as elementary school in preparation for College Bound Type Programs in high school.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Trauma-Informed Care in Florida Child Care Centers

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: adverse childhood experiences, child care, early childhood, florida, trauma, trauma informed care

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: There has been an increased interest in trauma-informed care practices in Florida to support children and families across the state who are currently dealing with trauma effects (Florida Department of Children and Families [DCF], 2019). My study sought to understand better the multiple experiences of child care center directors implementing trauma informed care practices after completing the Department's approved TICD course. The trauma-informed care 40-hour course for center directors was launched in 2019 and has been completed by more than 850 child care center directors throughout the state of Florida. I conducted a qualitative multi-site case study using the implementation model. As for sampling, I used a two-tier sampling structure: convenience and critical-case. I conducted one-on-one remote in-depth interviews with 11 child care directors in Miami-Dade County currently implementing trauma-informed care practices. The analytic approach was based on Creswell's Spiral, allowing me to review data multiple times while processing (Creswell, 2013). Overall, directors shared their willingness to assist at-risk children and families in their serving area by helping children cope with their ACEs. The findings are here presented by research question as follows: TICP strategies, directors’ challenges, and children behavior. As a result of the study, several recommendations were made to the Florida Department of Children and Families, Child Care Policy Administration, child care practitioners implementing trauma-informed care, and future researchers of this problem of practice.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Asymptotics of Certain Short-Range Interactions on Rectifiable Sets and Beyond

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Energy and Polarization, Fractal Geometry, Geometric Measure Theory, Packing and Covering, Potential Theory, Renewal Theory

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: We study the asymptotics of various short-range interactions, namely, minimal Riesz $s$-energy, maximal Riesz $s$-polarization, best packing, and best covering, on sets satisfying minimal smoothness assumptions. In particular, we present the proof of the Poppy-Seed Bagel Theorem for polarization and covering on $(\mathcal{H}_d,d)$-rectifiable subsets of Euclidean space with like Hausdorff measure and Minkowski content. This represents the sealing of a gap in the generality of results that existed between energy and polarization. In practice, we verify the short-range properties of polarization and covering to deduce the first order asymptotic formulas for these quantities, depending in a universal fashion upon $\mathcal{H}_d(A)$. We simultaneously use the short range properties to deduce weak* uniformity of optima in the large configuration limit. Our results are sharp in the following sense: for sets lacking one of the regularity assumptions mentioned above, asymptotics do not depend on $\mathcal{H}_d(A)$ in the same way as stated there. \par The manuscript contains several of our results concerning asymptotics of short-range interactions on metrically separated self-similar fractals. Our primary result is the convergence of hyper-singular polarization on independent fractals. We further detail the proofs of convergence of minimal $s$-energy on lattice fractals along explicit subsequences, and the general non-existence of asymptotics for packing and covering on these sets. Taken with results of Lalley, the negative results provide a characterization of convergence for packing and covering on a given self-similar fractal in terms of the algebraic relationship between its contraction ratios. From the negative results, we also derive non-existence of asymptotics for energy and polarization, for sufficiently large parameter. \par Finally, we discuss some open problems concerning short-range interactions. We draw upon results of Falconer, Gatzouras, and Lapidus to conjecture about the universality of asymptotic formulas for packing and covering on some Minkowski measurable subsets of $\mathbb{R}$ with non-integer Minkowski dimension $d\in(0,1).$ Then, we view the Riesz $s$-energy of $N$-point configurations as a function of $N$ points in Euclidean space, and propose a rigorous study of the dynamics of gradient descent as a means of producing \textit{local} minima of Riesz $s$-energy on spheres. This leads us to conjecture that "bad" starting configurations make up a negligible proportion of all configurations with respect to $N$-fold surface measure.

DISS_description.DISS_title: MONOMER- AND POLYMER-BASED N-HETEROCYCLIC CARBENE COATING OF TRANSITION METAL CORE NANOCOLLOIDS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The unique size-dependent optical and physical properties of inorganic nanocrystals such as those made of metals and semiconductors have generated an enormous interest in exploiting them to develop a variety of applications. Due to their unique features, they have also been integrated into a variety of applications, including biological sensing, imaging, optoelectronic devices, and as fluorescent probes in biology. Growth of these materials using either hydrophilic or hydrophobic conditions yields nanocolloids that are not readily compatible with biological systems, due to either the hydrophobic nature of the ligands or the labile properties of the coatings. The main focus of this dissertation is to design and synthesis a series of molecular scale and multidentate N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC)-based ligands and apply them for the surface functionalization various inorganic nanocrystals and render them water soluble. We also summarize coordination interactions of NHC moieties with the gold surfaces to get better understanding about nature of NHC-Au bond. In Chapter 1, we summarize some of the basic optical and physical properties of inorganic nanomaterials including, quantum dots (QDs), gold nanoparticles (AuNPs), and gold nanoclusters (AuNCs). We briefly describe the history of growth strategies for preparing high quality QDs, AuNPs, and AuNCs. We then provide an overview of the surface functionalization methods to assemble colloidally stable and biocompatible nanoparticles followed by introducing the N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC)-based ligands as a novel metal anchoring group and their application in modern surface chemistry. In Chapter 2, we will focus on the synthesis of hydrophobic oleylamine-coated gold nanoparticles (OLA-AuNPs) and the surface coordination with N-Heterocyclic Carbenes (NHCs) relying on ligand substitution strategy. We detail the synthesis and characterization of three distinct water-compatible NHC-based ligands: an amine-modified small molecule, a monomeric NHC appended with a short poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) block, and a modified poly(isobutylene-alt-maleic anhydride), PIMA, that simultaneously presents multiple NHC groups and several short PEG chains. We find that rapid competitive ligation onto the AuNPs (often requiring several minutes of mixing) takes place regardless of the exact structure of the ligand. Furthermore, the long-term colloidal stability of the NHC-stabilized AuNPs have been tested after phase transfer to water, a highly challenging chemical venue for such groups due to their moisture sensitive nature. Our experimental data show that the multidentate NHC polymer coating exhibits the highest affinity to AuNPs, which manifests in long-term colloidal stability in buffer media, absence of any aggregation or degradation build up for at least one year of storage. In addition, the NHC-polymer-coated AuNPs exhibit long term resistance to competition from reducing small molecules such as dithiothreitol, DTT. In Chapter 3, we introduce a top-down etching strategy using poly (ethylene glycol)-appended-NHC (PEG-NHC) ligands to promote surface digestion of gold nanoparticles (AuNPs). We find that under long term incubation conditions using excess molar ratios of PEG-NHC ligands, with respect to AuNPs, progressive etching of Au surfaces takes place. This progressively alters the plasmon absorption features, yielding the formation of NHC-Au complexes. This top-down etching method has provided us insights about the nature and strength of coordination interactions of NHC groups with Au surfaces; these interactions are inherent controlled by the σ-donating nature (soft Lewis base) of NHC which match the soft acidic nature of Au surfaces, resulting in very strong coordination interactions and binding. We use UV-vis absorption measurements to monitor the transformation process, where loss of plasmonic features of AuNPs with time takes place. We further characterize the digestion kinetics by extracting a characteristic time which is found to depend among others on the ligand to AuNP molar excess. We then combine these data with 2-D 1H, 13C NMR spectroscopy, matrix assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI), and transmission electron microscopy measurements to identify the structure and chemical nature of the resulting NHC-PEG-Au complexes. In Chapter 4, we describe the formation of fluorescent blue emitting ultrasmall gold nanoclusters (Au NCs), following the digestion process described in Chapter 3 above, achieved under thermal treatment. This route offers an elegant way to produce stable and homogeneously dispersed AuNCs. Specifically, we show that heating of Au-NHC complexes triggers the formation of ultra-small gold nanoclusters that are fluorescent in the blue region of the optical spectrum upon UV excitation. Here, the starting non-fluorescent NHC-Au(I) complexes undergo aurophilic interactions (as is the tendency for gold(I) compounds) and form blue fluorescent small size nanoclusters. We carry out a thorough characterization of the nanoclusters using analytical techniques such as UV-vis absorption, fluorescence spectroscopy and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy. Among others, we find that these nanoclusters show the excitation maximum at 380 nm and the emission maximum at 460 nm. Transmission electron microscopic analysis shows that most of these particles are <1 nm. In Chapter 5, we provide a summary of the work assembled in this dissertation focusing on coordination interactions of N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC)-based ligands with the inorganic nanocrystals, along with the future research directions that expand on the ligation of NHC ligands with other transition metal cores including iron, silver, and platinum nanoparticles and their potential applications.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Teacher Perceptions of Beginner-Level Piano Technique and Injury Prevention

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Beginner Piano Lessons, Injury Prevention, Piano Pedagogy, Piano Technique, Playing-Related Musculoskeletal Disorders

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Many studies have been conducted examining musicians’ injuries and their prevention; however, most of this research focuses on the advanced pianist. Pedagogues and researchers agree that the early stages of piano study are crucial for developing proper habits regarding piano technique, and many believe that poor piano technique can be a factor in playing-related injury. An examination of piano teachers’ perceptions and practices regarding beginner-level technique and injury prevention is necessary in order to further investigate and understand the causes and solutions to this medical phenomenon. The purpose of this mixed methods study was to investigate current perspectives and perceptions of pre-college piano teachers regarding teaching technique to the beginner-level student and the relationship those perspectives have with injury prevention. Several factors were examined including the extent these teachers’ strategies reflected existing research concerning injury prevention and technique. Influences such as method books or prior education were also assessed to determine the root source of pedagogical choices. The researcher created a questionnaire that was distributed to pre-college piano teachers from across the United States. A total of 216 participants responded to the survey. The respondents answered questions regarding (I) demographic information; (II) teaching technique perspectives and practices; (III) method book information; and (IV) teaching injury prevention perspectives and practices. Both quantitative and qualitative data were collected. Results suggested that many teachers do believe the relationship between beginner-level technique instruction and injury prevention exists; however, the emphasis each participant places on certain techniques varies across demographic groups. When teachers were divided into groups according to their preferred method books, the order in which they introduced technical skills to students varied. Emphasis on various skills also differed when participants were organized into groups according to their personal experiences with playing-related musculoskeletal disorders. Other demographic groups such as the primary age group taught seemed to have little bearing on the responses. According to a pair of Pearson Correlation Coefficients, weak positive relationships were found to exist between the participants’ awareness of injury prevention and their education level and between their awareness and their amount of teaching experience. A series of open-ended questions allowed for the participating teachers to describe their teaching philosophies and strategies in their own words. Many commented positively on the importance of teaching technique while others detailed tactics they used in teaching students. Some described strategies they used at various stages of learning. A few respondents even reported having no specific philosophies regarding the subject matter. These responses were also compared to existing research literature concerning piano technique. Many mentioned strategies that have been shown to benefit students in the injury prevention area include slow practice, warming up, and teaching students to avoid tension in their playing apparatus. While some stated that they often delay serious technical study until later in the student’s playing career, many comments were made about prioritizing technique in order to prevent playing issues which many researchers have concluded as best practice for piano teachers. The prevalence of body awareness and technique methodology training was also surveyed. A majority (54.41%) of participants reported they had received some sort of training although that education varied from attending a local music teachers workshop to being certified in popular methods such as Alexander Technique or the Taubman Approach. Those who indicated more specific and detailed training often provided meticulous responses concerning their teaching philosophies. The researcher recommends for all beginner-level piano teachers to prioritize healthy piano technique with their students including using the parents of young students as a helpful resource to aid in the child’s development. Teachers who feel inadequately prepared to aid students in this area should seek further education through workshops, books, conferences, and other opportunities to better equip themselves for teaching. This study provides the basis for more research to be conducted on beginner-level piano technique in order to assist in the prevention of future injuries and to promote healthy and fulfilling piano playing.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Student perceptions of and preferences for online instructor course introductions

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Online instructors utilize instructional strategies to mitigate challenges that arise from transactional distance. These strategies can also facilitate establishing instructor social presence and identity, which is a common concern in online learning contexts. Effective online course introductions provide an opportunity for instructors to introduce themselves to online learners and model effective self-disclosures early in the course. Introductions help online learners know more about their course instructors and help them have a sense of what kind of an instructor they will be engaging in learning interactions with.Although course introductions are common first-day-of-the-class activities, there is limited empirical research on what students like to know about their instructors at the start of a course. Furthermore, previous studies demonstrate inconsistent findings regarding student perceptions of and preferences for the timing and type of instructor self-disclosures that are appropriate in an educational context. This exploratory study uses survey design to examine undergraduate and graduate students’ perceptions of and preferences for online instructor course introductions. Participants were recruited from a university’s research pool. The data set included 110 responses that were analyzed using descriptive statistics and content analysis. Findings show that it is important for online learners to know about their instructors, preferably their professional qualifications. When the instructor feels like a real person, students feel like they learn more. Most students turn to multiple different sources to learn more about their instructors even before a class begins. Reading the instructor’s course introduction is the most common approach to learning more about the instructor, while looking up the instructor on social media is the least common approach. Aligned with knowing more about the instructor’s professional qualifications, students find instructor self-disclosures about professional qualifications (e.g., course information, prior professional experience, college experiences, prior education, and hobbies) more appropriate than personal life details (e.g., personal opinions, relationship information, religious affiliation, socio-economic status, political affiliations, and financial information). Course information related disclosures had the highest approval ratings, while financial information had the least. Most students like to know what their online instructors look and sound like. Sharing instructor photos and videos as part of online course introductions had high approval ratings. Participants prefer instructor photo as a professional photo or headshot more than an informal photo or snapshot and a selfie. Moreover, instructor photos related to profession had the highest approval ratings in terms of types of photos that an instructor can add as part of course introduction, followed by pets, travel, family, and food. Introduction videos should be shot in the instructor’s office, followed by in a classroom, in their home, and outdoors. When asked how they perceive an online instructor based on a course introduction with no self-disclosure and with prior professional experiences and hobbies self-disclosures, students perceive the latter as more friendly, approachable, interested in their learning, and interested in the class. Moreover, they reported higher ratings of willingness to email the instructor and visit the instructor in office hour. This finding suggests that appropriate self-disclosures early at the start of a course might help instructors reduce tensions around transactional distance and help them be perceived as real, and increase student willingness to interact with their instructors. The findings of this study challenge instructional practices in which instructors self-disclose personal and vulnerable information early in the course and personal information in general. Overall, this exploratory study provide additional insights to the literature on social presence and identity as well as instructor self-disclosure in online learning contexts. Limitations were presented and implications for theory, research, and practice were discussed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: DATA-DRIVEN DECISION-MAKING PRACTICES: AN EXPLORATORY CASE STUDY OF THE DIVISION OF STUDENT AFFAIRS AT SOUTH COUNTY COLLEGE

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Data, Improvement, Student Affairs

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study aimed to address the state of data driven decision practices within the Division of Student Affairs at South County College. Framed by an exploratory qualitative case study, this project conducted semi-structured interviews of directors of student affairs and a document analysis of annual reports of the seven departments that constitute the Division. This exploratory case study set out to investigate how the departments within the Division define data, the practices and use of data, and the challenges that faced when managing data. The results from this study reported that participants defined data by the source’s name, platform’s name or simply the name of the office from where they retrieve the data. Participants also highlighted the important role data plays in their department’s ability to identify and attend to students’ needs. This approach connects with the findings on how student affairs personnel use data, the use of data to make improvement in their services and operations offered to students, and to inform their supervisors, leadership, and the college community about their departments’ accomplishments and advances of their goals. When addressing participants’ challenges on managing data, access to data is the major challenge emphasized by participants. This challenge of accessibility to data is described in two ways: more data access for staff and colleagues; and more communication about data availability. In addition, availability of data training is another challenge identified by participants. When talking about what type of training or data literacy is needed, their perception varies upon their experience and contact with data. Accordingly, this study proposes a series of recommendations to support continuous improvement of data practices within the Division of Student Affairs. These recommendations are: enhance data processes and procedures for data access, expand data literacy training, and improve communication and collaboration among the different colleges’ stakeholders.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THE APPLICATION OF VENEZUELAN MARACAS IN WESTERN ART AND CONTEMPORARY MUSIC

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Errata, Maracas, Notation, Pedagogy, Percussion, Venezuela

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this document is to examine contemporary performance practice of the maracas and how application of specific techniques can prove beneficial to standard orchestral and modern art music forms. There is little extant pedagogy in the field, therefore awareness of recent trends (emphasis on world music in the classical percussion curriculum) will hopefully cultivate new options and ideas concerning interpretation of western notation and performance practice. It is important to understand the instruments themselves—the construction and physics to be sure, but also production and practice. Maracas come in many different forms, so it is essential to illuminate options including mass production versus those made by hand. Perhaps more importantly, a brief overview of traditional Venezuelan music is necessary to connect culture with performance practice. Several genres of Venezuelan music will be discussed as well as the instruments specific to those genres. And finally, this document will provide guidance regarding adaptation of current notation and their application to significant works including maracas.

DISS_attachment.DISS_file_name: Naked And on Fire Rehearsal P-End Excerpt.mp4
Sonoran Desert Holiday 6 After Measure 150 Excerpt.mp4

DISS_description.DISS_title: A COMPREHENSIVE APPROACH TO PROFESSIONAL AUDITION RECORDINGS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Audio, Camera, Microphone, Music, Recording, Video

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This treatise aims to explore the evolution of pre-screening audition requirements for college music programs and demonstrate best practices for producing professional pre-screening audition recordings for graduate school, competitions, and music festivals. By learning and applying professional audio-video recording skills, students can learn to record their pre-screening recordings for various platforms, providing opportunities for education and performance while emphasizing entrepreneurship and advancement.While all remote audition recordings require video (and audio), the guidelines and technical requirements surrounding the submission process are evolving annually. As students plan and prepare multiple lists of audition repertoire, the importance of the actual recording process is often overlooked. Post-pandemic technological advances in media (specifically audio/video and file transfer/shared media platforms) have provided numerous opportunities to simultaneously capture HD video and high-resolution audio. The first part of this document focuses on university music programs and their pre-screening audition requirements. Chapters 2 and 3 introduce basic audio and video terminology, gear, and recording fundamentals. Chapter 4 features in-depth explanations of how the materials learned in chapters 2 and 3 can be applied to capture pre-screening recordings at the highest level. Chapter 5 contains guiding wisdom and thoughts offered by the author to college music students interested in learning audio-video recording, including starting a recording business, how to find work, and the variety of opportunities available to college music students interested in taking up recording as an additional source of income and/or potential career path. Finally, Part Two contains supplemental advanced audio and video terminology for those interested in further study.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Situated Knowledges in Different World Regions: Reflections on Mosquito Control and Malaria Prevention Knowledge and Curricular Approaches to Bring Diverse Global Knowledges into World Regional Geography

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The primary objective of this dissertation is to scrutinize knowledge production. We recognize the work produced and shared by feminist geographers such as Donna Haraway and Gillian Rose that have asserted systemic biases in how knowledge is produced and reproduced. This work, like others before, will push beyond the ‘vantage point of master subject’ (Haraway 1988) and engage a variety of participants and research methodologies to answer our research questions. In doing so, this dissertation aims to add a mixed methods approach to the growing body of literature to probe the partiality of knowledge (Nightingale 2003). This dissertation utilizes multiple methodologies to conduct research to demonstrate the importance of recognizing the multitude of knowledge sources when conducting research and aims to amplify situated and local knowledge, particularly from the Global South. To date, there remain significant barriers for underrepresented perspectives and voices to reach academia and the published literature (Hedding and Breetzke 2021), for which this dissertation hopes to improve.Malaria remains the world’s deadliest vector-borne disease, resulting in over 200 million human cases and more than 400,000 deaths annually. While some progress has been made in combating malaria, Sumba Island, Indonesia has lagged much of the rest of Indonesia and the region in lowering malaria infections. Chapters 2-3 survey communities of East Sumba Island, Indonesia to understand knowledge, attitudes, and practices of mosquito control and malaria prevention. Chapter 2 employs a qualitative approach to investigate knowledge, attitudes, and practices surrounding mosquito control and prevention methods in East Sumba Regency, Indonesia. While malaria is under control in much of Indonesia, transmission in Sumba Island remains high, with an incidence as high as 500 cases per 1000 people per year in some areas. This chapter explores the use of insecticide treated nets (ITNs), traditional Sumbanese mosquito control methods, as well as the role of community-based health workers (kaders) and integrated health service posts (posyandu), to combat malaria. Focus group discussions (n = 7) and key informant interviews (n = 14) were conducted with religious leaders, health workers, and women’s group leaders and were stratified by urban/rural location and malaria incidence. Results indicate that environmental conditions, such as high temperatures, were deterrents to regular use. Furthermore, our results suggest that community-embedded health workers, kaders, and health service posts, posyandu, play an important role in information dissemination related to mosquitoes and mosquito-borne diseases as well as the distribution and use of ITNs. Chapter 3 aims to investigate local knowledge, attitudes, and practices related to mosquito control and malaria prevention in East Sumba Island, Indonesia through a cross-sectional household survey (n = 757) informed by previously collected qualitative data found in Chapter 2. The cross-sectional household surveys were conducted across six study sites in East Sumba Regency, Indonesia in urban and rural areas with both high and low malaria incidence. Logistic/multinomial regressions examined sociodemographic relationships to themes found within the household surveys. Further, this study utilizes and expands the traditional Health Belief Model to understand mosquito control and malaria prevention behaviors, particularly as they are impacted by gender, socioeconomics, and geographic location. This study uncovered survey respondents’ attitudes, perceptions, and acceptance of the novel spatial repellent use (n = 719) with 95% of study participants expressing a likelihood of using spatial repellent. This demonstrated early buy-in to novel techniques to control mosquitoes. Additionally, results from this study include the influence of risk perception on a willingness to take actions to control mosquitoes to prevent malaria such as clearing tall grass and/or brush, eliminating mosquito breeding habitats, willingness to sell or deliver mosquito control products, and a willingness to educate the community about such measures. Chapter 4 investigates the role of films used as a key component for World Geography (GEA 1000), an undergraduate course that completes a university-wide cross-cultural studies requirement. Utilizing films, particularly those sourced from underrepresented regions, introduced students to local and situated knowledges outside their typical perspectives and lived experiences. The course was taught remotely during a six-week Summer session in 2020 during the SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) pandemic. The films used cover a wide range of topics such as poverty, war, climate change, migration, and other key subjects. Upon watching the films, students were then instructed to take a short assessment to evaluate their comprehension of the film content. At the completion of the course, students expressed (through course evaluations) that this format helped contextualize geographic themes and world events as well as served as a learning tool in addition to more traditional methods.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Uncovering Word Painting and Motivic Structures Within Paul Hindemith's Das Marienleben

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Das Marienleben, Motive, Paul Hindemith, Word Painting

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this study is to highlight word painting and motivic material in Paul Hindemith’s Das Marienleben. Throughout history, these devices have been compositional techniques used by many composers. This treatise will be helpful in interpreting Hindemith’s Das Marienleben and approaching the music from an experimental view. The life of Mary is shrouded in mystery; the Bible says little about her before she is visited by Gabriel or after Jesus ascends to heaven. Rilke uses poetic license to fill out the unknown details of Mary’s life and Hindemith interprets the poetry by creating a dynamic song cycle that starts with Mary’s birth and concludes with her own ascension into heaven. This study includes figures with highlighted motives, discussion of significant moments within the music, and scriptural passages and poetry that introduce each song. Readers will also find a complete IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet) transcription, a glossary of terminology, and a translated edition of Hindemith’s opening remarks on the cycle. The last scholarly writings about Das Marienleben were published over twenty years ago and this treatise aims to bring a new perspective in approaching his music.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Lyre as a Sonic Icon in the Italian Renaissance

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Early Music, Italian Renaissance, Kithara, Lyre, Marsilio Ficino, Occultism

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This thesis explores the musical, metaphorical, and metaphysical symbolism of the lyre as a term, as an image, and as a physical instrument in fourteenth through sixteenth centuries Italy, analyzing evidence to argue that it acted as a sonic icon. The term sonic icon refers to the visual and sonic importance of this instrument held by scholars, musicians, and artists during this period. This can be seen through multivalences surrounding the lyre as a term, image, or stringed instrument of many types, as a mythical and philosophical symbol, and as a tool for musical performances, including those which involved healing and connections to esoteric practices.
